revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-11 23:31:52.000000000', 'message': "Simple checks for instance user data.

Check that instance user data wont be truncated, and that it is
valid base64 data. This partially resolves bug 1035055. I don't
love the hard coded maximum length, but I haven't worked out how
to get sqlalchemy to tell me the maximum size of the data type.

commit_message:
Simple checks for instance user data.

Check that instance user data wont be truncated, and that it is
valid base64 data. This partially resolves bug 1035055. I don't
love the hard coded maximum length, but I haven't worked out how
to get sqlalchemy to tell me the maximum size of the data type.

Change-Id: I045d6b4481563d01cae371cf61a91781cfed6f4b

commit_message:
Set task_state=None when finished snapshotting.

Reverts part of recent reverts_task_state commit
d8d7100f8c10ecd388d1943bee9298a913a6990a which removed
code that resets the task_state to None once a snapshot has
been completed.

Fixes LP Bug #1036835.

Change-Id: I7d30d16ca110f022b0d1f6b2fb05ba3aa52fa4d1

commit_message:
Update python-quantumclient dep to require >=2.0

Horizon integration with Quantum requires Quantum API v2.0

The first python-quantumclient release with support for the v2.0 API is
version 2.0, so we should require at least that version.  This version
was pushed to PyPi today:

http://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-quantumclient/2.0

Change-Id: Id1656241e05f62bc22c874e3c05ba711f150e784

commit_message:
Switch to using cinderclient.

This is practically a transparent switch since it was
copied out of novaclient and maintains API compatibility.

NOTE: this will fail until python-cinderclient is published
to PyPI properly.

Implements blueprint switch-to-cinder-client

Change-Id: Ic8cd6660735e172ff5d3402952265a15dc15f9e5

Cleanup on nova.console.api.py for defined vars and function.

There is a mixup between instance_id and instance_uuid here. Also,
it referencing _translate_id_if_necessary as _translate_uuid_if_necessary,
so making few changes to get this in order. Fixes bug 1014796.

Change-Id: I636e720bd62634feb700d5b10c613e0a9c8298bf
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup console api

Cleanup on nova.console.api.py for defined vars and function.

There is a mixup between instance_id and instance_uuid here. Also,
it referencing _translate_id_if_necessary as _translate_uuid_if_necessary,
so making few changes to get this in order. Fixes bug 1014796.

Change-Id: I636e720bd62634feb700d5b10c613e0a9c8298bf

* Print a WARNING line to stderr when bin/glance is called
* Raise a UserWarning on 'import glance.client'
* Implements bp glance-deprecate-client

Change-Id: Iabce7569d28c5dc73b5e1ceb55e4e4f2fc47727b
"}]
commit_message:
Mark bin/glance as deprecated

* Add a WARNING to the usage of bin/glance
* Print a WARNING line to stderr when bin/glance is called
* Raise a UserWarning on 'import glance.client'
* Implements bp glance-deprecate-client

Change-Id: Iabce7569d28c5dc73b5e1ceb55e4e4f2fc47727b

commit_message:
Add availability_zone support for volume creation.

Add '--availability_zone' flag to 'create' sub command in order to allow
user to speicify target availability zone for volume.

Also fix library description in setup.py

Change-Id: Ice3c9a550dcc486208208074730da13c64a6719b

I'm a bit closer now.  I got 'admin_pass' into the config drive version without going in the web view of the metadata service by adding 'extra_md' flag.  This is expected to be a dict, and then is added to the data at the root via {}.update.

The next thing to do is to get the netcfg into the web view.  I intend to separate out the population of the 'net' from virt/libvirt/driver.py and then use that code both there and in the web view.

This will also help me to better access to the network information for adding 'hostname', 'public-hostname', 'public-ip' and the like to openstack/latest/metadata.js

awesome work. We can mark blueprint complete once this gets in. for the todos we can make bugs about them.'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-08-14 16:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Very nice work!'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-08-14 16:48:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Few nits inline.

I guess I'm just not sure about the metadata web service at all. With the ability to use a config drive or use injected files into a partition on the disk image, I just don't see the need to have some web service publishing information that is already on the filesystem.

I also don't understand why we need to perpetuate the EC2 hard-coded 169.254.169.254 thing, bolting on now an /openstack endpoint. The 169.254.169.254 is Ec2-specific and should stay that way IMHO.

Best,

jay"}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-08-14 17:00:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-08-14 17:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

With reguard to "why do we need the metadata web service if we have config-drive"...

The metadata web service is dynamic, and it is expected that in the future we'll want to do some things from the instance to that service.  (you can surely imagine wanting to delete data once it was consumed).

As mentioned in the commit messsage, I would like there to be a 'metadata_service_url' that would be http://169.254.169.254/openstack but would be 'None' (or non-present) if there was no MD. And ideally that would be configurable.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-08-14 17:29:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is the best thing since sliced bread!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-14 18:00:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

jay, the idea is that config drive and metadata provide the exact same information (except for the small distinction that metadata server is always current, and config drive is just data from boot time) and that an openstack cloud has to implement at least one of them.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-14 18:03:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

comments on instance metadata inline."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-08-14 18:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-14 18:48:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-08-14 18:48:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Vish, thanks for the explanation there... removing the instance: prefix satisfies my curmudgeonliness (at least for today). I still think the metadata service can be made more OpenStack-y, but this isn't the right place to discuss that. I'll try and put some code together in the G timeframe.

best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 19:03:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Works for me

[{'created': '2012-08-10 21:29:37.000000000', 'message': "continued work on config-drive-v2 and openstack metadata api

This continues the work Michael did on config-drive-v2

Things added:
 * web service /openstack/2012-08-10 with:
   user-data
   metadata.js
 * web service supporting /openstack/content

The metadata.js now contains
  uuid: <instance uuid>
  meta: if meta tags provided any prefixed with 'instance:' will be
        available here
  admin_pass: if configured and provided it will show up here
  files:
     This is a list of dicts, where each dict has 2 fields:
       * 'path' (the path provided)
       * 'content_id': the location in /content/ that will give the content
  public-keys:
     Dict of keyname : value

Change-Id: I6b9097624a9c1a972e4851d79f6d557376f59d32
TODO:
 * rework config drive builder to use the content in base.py
 * test rendering of config drive
 * get the rendered network template file
 * from [1] want to add other items into openstack metadata
   local-hostname, public-hostname (and IPs)
   keystone-endpoint
   url of metadata service

"}, {'created': '2012-08-12 03:34:55.000000000', 'message': "continued work on config-drive-v2 and openstack metadata api

This continues the work Michael did on blueprint config-drive-v2

Things added:
 * web service /openstack/2012-08-10 with:
   user-data
   metadata.json
 * web service supporting /openstack/content

Things changed:
 * Changed the name 'files' (/openstack/files) to be 'content'
   This is to be more generic and apply to future re-use of it
   for some purpose other than personalities (injected_files)

The metadata.json now contains
  uuid: <instance uuid>
  meta: if meta tags provided any prefixed with 'instance:' will be
        available here
  files:
     This is a list of dicts, where each dict has 2 fields:
       * 'path' (the path provided)
       * 'content_id': the location in /content/ that will give the content
  public-keys:
     Dict of keyname : value

TODO:
 * nova/api/metadata/base.py: get the rendered network template file
 * want to add other items into openstack metadata
   * local-hostname, public-hostname (and IPs)
   * keystone-endpoint
   * url of metadata service: ideally only show this if there
     is a web service available.  the path seems hard coded at the moment
     to be http://169.254.169.254/openstack, but I do not know if there
     is a way to determine if one is present or not.
 * nova/api/metadata/base.py: add 'admin_pass' to the metadata service.
   I was unable to see how I could reference FLAGS.libvirt_inject_password.
   Being libvirt specific, this doesn't really seem like the right place to
   look anyway.  Also, vishy commented that perhaps it should not be in the web
   service.  We could make this available only in config-drive.
 * Figure out if injected_files (personalities) are available at all after
   instance launch.  If they're not, then they can't be made available in the
   web service.
 * document config-drive-v2

Change-Id: I6b9097624a9c1a972e4851d79f6d557376f59d32

"}, {'created': '2012-08-13 20:22:27.000000000', 'message': 'continued work on config-drive-v2 and openstack metadata api

This continues the work Michael did on blueprint config-drive-v2

Things added:
 * web service /openstack/2012-08-10 with:
   user-data
   metadata.json
 * web service supporting /openstack/content

Things changed:
 * Changed the name 'files' (/openstack/files) to be 'content'
   This is to be more generic and apply to future re-use of it
   for some purpose other than personalities (injected_files)
 * 'content_path' is a attribute of each of the entries in the 'files'
   its value is the path from the openstack metadata service root to
   where the content is located.

   This means that the user does not have to know anything explicit about
   '/content'.  They just have to take the 'content_path' and append it
   to the top level entry point of metadata service.

   Explicit example:
   http://169.254.169.254/openstack/2012-08-10/metadata.json
   has:
     files[{path: "/etc/passwd", content_path: "/content/0001"}]
   To get the file, user appends 'content_path' to
     http://169.254.169.254/openstack

The metadata.json now contains
  uuid: <instance uuid>
  meta: if meta tags provided any prefixed with 'instance:' will be
        available here
  files:
     This is a list of dicts, where each dict has 2 fields:
       * 'path' (the path provided)
       * 'content_id': the location in /content/ that will give the content
  public-keys:
     Dict of keyname : value

TODO:
 * nova/api/metadata/base.py: get the rendered network template file
   both in web service and in config drive.
 * want to add other items into openstack metadata
   * local-hostname, public-hostname (and IPs)
   * keystone-endpoint
   * url of metadata service: ideally only show this if there
     is a web service available.  the path seems hard coded at the moment
     to be http://169.254.169.254/openstack, but I do not know if there
     is a way to determine if one is present or not.
 * document config-drive-v2

Change-Id: I6b9097624a9c1a972e4851d79f6d557376f59d32

commit_message:
continue config-drive-v2, add openstack metadata api

This continues the work Michael did on blueprint config-drive-v2

Things added:
 * web service /openstack/2012-08-10 with:
   user_data
   meta_data.json
 * web service supporting /openstack/content

Things changed:
 * Changed the name 'files' (/openstack/files) to be 'content'
   This is to be more generic and apply to future re-use of it
   for some purpose other than personalities (injected_files)
 * 'meta_data.json' and 'user_data' are used for openstack
 * 'user-data' (without .raw) in the ec2 config drive rendering
 * 'content_path' is a attribute of each of the entries in the 'files'
   its value is the path from the openstack metadata service root to
   where the content is located.

   This means that the user does not have to know anything explicit about
   '/content'.  They just have to take the 'content_path' and append it
   to the top level entry point of metadata service.

   Explicit example:
   http://169.254.169.254/openstack/2012-08-10/meta_data.json
   has:
     files[{path: "/etc/passwd", content_path: "/content/0001"}]
   To get the file, user appends 'content_path' to
     http://169.254.169.254/openstack
 * network config (Template) is available in /content also, and
   the key that points to it is 'network_config'. This occurs only
   if there are network's that are "injected" (same behavior as previously)

The meta_data.json now contains
  uuid: <instance uuid>
  meta: meta tags provided they will appear in a dict here
  files:
     This is a list of dicts, where each dict has 2 fields:
       * 'path' (the path provided)
       * 'content_id': the location in /content/ that will give the content
  public-keys:
     Dict of keyname : value
  network_config:
     This is a dict, containing 'content_path' and 'name' (network_config)
  hostname: the hostname
  name: the nova boot name

TODO:
 * want to add other items into openstack metadata
   * public-hostname
   * IP addresses
   * keystone-endpoint
   * url of metadata service: ideally only show this if there
     is a web service available.  the path seems hard coded at the moment
     to be http://169.254.169.254/openstack, but I do not know if there
     is a way to determine if one is present or not.
 * document config-drive-v2

Change-Id: I6b9097624a9c1a972e4851d79f6d557376f59d32

[{'created': '2012-08-13 06:39:23.000000000', 'message': 'Update stack.sh for Quantum linuxbridge plugin changes.

With support for multiple physical networks being added to the Quantum
linuxbridge plugin via https://review.openstack.org/#/c/10938/, the
configuration of physical interfaces for the agent has changed. The
physical_interface_mappings variable, a list of mappings between
physical network names and physical interfaces, replaces the
physical_interface variable.

Also, all remnants of the V1 quantum API have been removed, so the
target_v2_api variable no longer needs to be set.

Change-Id: I5f9be772f71b5ce3fd92eb258e0131705d341647

commit_message:
Update stack.sh for Quantum linuxbridge plugin changes.

With support for multiple physical networks being added to the Quantum
linuxbridge plugin via https://review.openstack.org/#/c/10938/, the
configuration of physical interfaces for the agent has changed. The
physical_interface_mappings variable, a list of mappings between
physical network names and physical interfaces, replaces the
physical_interface variable.

Also, all remnants of the V1 quantum API have been removed, so the
target_v2_api variable no longer needs to be set.

Change-Id: I5f9be772f71b5ce3fd92eb258e0131705d341647

"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 14:54:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I added a validation logic to syspanel instance launch workflow according to you comment.
It checks the network tenant ownership matches the tenant_id specified in the "Project and User" tab.

However some issues are remaining. It seems to be a bug or a limitation not related to Quantum support.

(1)
Help message of "Project & User" tab says that "Admin users may optionally select the project and user for whom the instance should be created."
But in AdminLaunchInstance:handle() project_id specified in launching panel is not referred and an instance is launched in the current project.
In addition, api.nova.server_create() does not provide a method to launch an instance by different project/user.

Due to this limitation, launching an instance will fail unless all of the following three are same: project_id specified in "Project & User" tab, tenant_id(project_id) of the selected network(s), and project_id of the current session.
Ideally launching an instance should success if "project_id specified in 'Project & User' tab" and "tenant_id(project_id) of the selected network(s)" are same.

To address it, keystone token seems to be required, but I am not sure how to do it.

(2)
I implemented a validation logic as syspanel/instances/workflows.py AdminLaunchInstance:validate() method.
I tryied to raise WorkflowValidationError according to the docstring of horizon.workflows.base.validate(),
but exception seems not to be caught appropriately and exception message passsed was lost.
Thus I use messages.error() to return an error message to a user and then return False in validate().

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 16:01:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 16:16:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python26/648/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python27/648/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-selenium/157/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/7767/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-08-14 17:26:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The problems with tenants in syspanel are quite old and well known :)

I like the validation. Just one more thing - it would be better to pass the network name (add it in 'populate_network_choices') and show it in the error message it is much more informative to know which the problem network(s) is/are..."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 17:55:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 18:02:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I added network name into the error message as you suggested.

I hope the problems with syspanel will be fixed by Folsom release since it is a little confusing.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 18:08:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

commit_message:
Specify tenant_id when retrieving network list from Quantum.

Fixes bug 1036153

If a user has admin role, network list returned by Quantum API contains
networks that does not belong to that tenant. As a result networks owned
by other tenants are listed in "Network" tab of "Launch Intance" menu.
Thus we need to specify tenant_id when calling network_list() to
retrieve only the networks available for the tenant.

In addition this commit added a validation logic to syspanel instance
launching workflow. It checks whether the owner tenant of the requested
network(s) matches the tenant specified in the launching panel.

Change-Id: Ieadf33f0a41247b126669f2f1f2c1d29be01e4e9

commit_message:
Return values from wrapped functions in decorators

Calling compute manager methods requires that the decorators
return the value from the underlying function.

This doesn't actually change any return values from methods, because
all existing methods effectively return None.

Fixes bug 1036793

Change-Id: I64eea506ee1395678a7de3c6963a3da8e40d6962

'}, {'account_id': 1894, 'date': '2012-08-14 19:39:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Devstack for this plugin: https://github.com/r-mibu/devstack/tree/quantum-nec-plugin .
I prepared wrapper script which installs trema(required by this plugin) and run this devstack: https://github.com/nec-openstack/quantum-openflow-plugin/tree/folsom/quickstart .

I changed plugin-specific port information 'DevInfo' to 'PortInfo'. At nova quantumv2 support, a VIF ID on Nova is port ID on Quantum, so the plugin can get port ID directly from Open vSwitch DB in witch LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver registers VIF IDs as 'iface-id'.
In Nova integration test with Patch Set 4, I found a bug that all port never activate due to mismatch of 'device_id'. This plugin treated 'device_id' as VIF ID, while Nova sets VM ID to 'device_id'. I'm not sure that 'device_id' is proper attribute to register VM ID. Anyway, this bug was fixed in Patch Set 5."}, {'account_id': 1894, 'date': '2012-08-14 19:39:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 19:39:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

commit_message:
Trivial openvswitch plugin cleanup.

Part of provider-networks phase 3 development, but merging separately
to avoid confusion later.

- eliminate target_v2_api config variable
- eliminate old V1 version of Port
- remove unused import

Change-Id: I913def752ec537a7e74a6173f2b6f82372a4dce8

Cheers,
Eoghan"}]

commit_message:
Add separate notification handler for instance flavor

This notification handler records a meter event with the
instance flavor included, making it easier to query
for the amount of time an instance existed as a specific
flavor.

Change-Id: Ic162ac021f864c2a98c47127288867e940469ceb
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Change instance meter type

The instance meter type was set to "cumulative" but it
should be "absolute" so the aggregation code in the
API knows how to reduce the values.

Change-Id: I5bd44958c86d0431d2b0e427c75be92cfecdb28b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Split the existing notification handlers up

We want to be able to enable and disable the handlers
for notification events individually. This change
splits them up so they are registered with separate
names to allow that.

This change also adds python-glanceclient as a test
dependency so we can import the test code from nova.

Change-Id: Icc07baba3f00294d8ee505a2cc82f65c0c7f4fc9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Driver for IBM XIV storage.

Volume driver for IBM XIV storage systems, along with unit tests. The
driver imports the xiv_openstack_box class, which is a closed-source
proxy available separately to IBM XIV customers.

Change-Id: I3a3ec8b1d3e3adf1895b4a0bbd86993010d2e447

commit_message:
Fix uuid related bug in console/api

A number of variables are undefined while refactoring uuid in
I4032419d66e9bbb17b770d8974a92a136bf9c5d2.
self._translate_uuid_if_necessary is also no longer available.
Those problems are fixed in this patch.

Change-Id: Ifb88b4faa11b2ba8178a9a705ba6da1e4d9b4182

Updates the instance type extra specs and volume type extra specs
create/update functions so that 'deleted' is treated as a boolean.

This resolves issues when trying to create/update extra specs
on Postgres.

Fixes LP Bug #1036287.

Change-Id: I7f38b40122240af3254d8a817f5144ce9fafd6db
"}]
commit_message:
Update extra specs calls to use deleted: False.

Updates the instance type extra specs and volume type extra specs
create/update functions so that 'deleted' is treated as a boolean.

This resolves issues when trying to create/update extra specs
on Postgres.

Fixes LP Bug #1036287.

Change-Id: I7f38b40122240af3254d8a817f5144ce9fafd6db

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-26 12:51:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Ok, looking at the current checks_instance_lock() first - couple of things:

1. checks_instance_lock() doesn't return anything if it succeeds - this means that any methods that are decorated with @checks_instance_lock and have a return value, should just have the return removed since it's clearly not used.

2. Am I correct that checks_instance_lock() currently just logs an error if its locked? No callers check for this and no errors are reported to the user? Then I think we should also remove the False return value from checks_instance_lock() since it's unused.

Unless I'm missing something, I think we should first get a cleanup patch in to address both of those things."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-26 12:54:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Wow, I see Russell has done a bunch of work on check_instance_lock() in I93e331706aed1c97877655ce54784a0dbd8de89e - that at least means we need a rebase."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-26 13:56:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Ok, dansmith and I just had a quick chat on IRC

I pointed out that when an action succeeds, we clear the task_state irrespective of what the current state is e.g. in reboot_instance()

    self._instance_update(context, instance['uuid'],
                          ...
                          task_state=None)

So there's no real need for this:

  @reverts_task_state((task_states.REBOOTING,))

it should be fine to clear the task_state in error irrespective of the current task_state"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-26 14:01:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Another observation on IRC

It does make sense to have two separate decorators because you can use @revert_take_state without @checks_instance_lock

However, it never makes sense to use @checks_instance_lock without @revert_task_state which suggests to me that if you decorate with @checks_instance_lock you should also have to add @revert_task_state - it should happen automatically'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-26 14:08:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Ok, see I8b49107d and I14581171'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-26 15:34:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-17 20:20:22.000000000', 'message': 'Revert task_state on failed start/stop/reboot actions

Right now, the task_state logic in compute/api.py can be broken, such
that instances can get stuck in an uneditable state if a start, stop,
or reboot action is performed that fails. The easiest way to reproduce
this is with admin locking, such as:

1. nova boot .... foo
2. nova lock foo (as admin)
3. nova stop foo (as user)
4. nova unlock foo (as admin)
5. nova stop foo (as either) -> fails due to task_state==stopping
6. nova start foo (as either) -> fails due to vm_state==active

The only way out of it is to delete the instance or hack the database.

This patch adds a revert_task_state() function to compute/manager.py,
which, upon failing the lock check, selectively reverts the instance
task_state back to None.

It also makes the test_lock() test pre-set the task_state before
attempting the ill-fated reboot action, and verify that it gets
reverted. It also adds test_lock_no_revert_invalid_state() to validate
that revert_task_state() does not blindly start reverting states not
in its map of sane ones.

Fixes bug 1025722

Change-Id: Id4358c508156c713cb953dfa0f01a6f598bc1e7d
'}, {'created': '2012-07-17 21:22:56.000000000', 'message': 'Revert task_state on failed start/stop/reboot actions

Right now, the task_state logic in compute/api.py can be broken, such
that instances can get stuck in an uneditable state if a start, stop,
or reboot action is performed that fails. The easiest way to reproduce
this is with admin locking, such as:

1. nova boot .... foo
2. nova lock foo (as admin)
3. nova stop foo (as user)
4. nova unlock foo (as admin)
5. nova stop foo (as either) -> fails due to task_state==stopping
6. nova start foo (as either) -> fails due to vm_state==active

The only way out of it is to delete the instance or hack the database.

This patch adds a revert_task_state() function to compute/manager.py,
which, upon failing the lock check, selectively reverts the instance
task_state back to None.

It also makes the test_lock() test pre-set the task_state before
attempting the ill-fated reboot action, and verify that it gets
reverted. It also adds test_lock_no_revert_invalid_state() to validate
that revert_task_state() does not blindly start reverting states not
in its map of sane ones.

Fixes bug 1025722

Change-Id: Id4358c508156c713cb953dfa0f01a6f598bc1e7d
'}, {'created': '2012-07-19 17:12:35.000000000', 'message': "Revert task_state on failed instance actions

Right now, the task_state logic in compute/api.py can be broken, such
that instances can get stuck in an uneditable state if an action is
performed that fails. The easiest way to reproduce this is with admin
locking, such as:

1. nova boot .... foo
2. nova lock foo (as admin)
3. nova stop foo (as user)
4. nova unlock foo (as admin)
5. nova stop foo (as either) -> fails due to task_state==stopping
6. nova start foo (as either) -> fails due to vm_state==active

The only way out of it is to delete the instance or hack the database.

This patch adds a reverts_task_state() decorator to compute/manager.py,
which, upon operation failure, selectively reverts the instance
task_state back to None.

It also adds a test_state_revert() test to verify that all the actions
marked for state reversion do the right thing. The new
test_no_revert_bad_state() test verifies that the decorator doesn't
arbitrarily revert any task_state.

Note that the existing admin password test was checking that the
task_state remained unmodified after failure, which is no longer
the expected or desired behavior.

Fixes bug 1025722

Change-Id: Id4358c508156c713cb953dfa0f01a6f598bc1e7d

1. nova boot .... foo
2. nova lock foo (as admin)
3. nova stop foo (as user)
4. nova unlock foo (as admin)
5. nova stop foo (as either) -> fails due to task_state==stopping
6. nova start foo (as either) -> fails due to vm_state==active

The only way out of it is to delete the instance or hack the database.

This patch adds a reverts_task_state() decorator to compute/manager.py,
which, upon operation failure, selectively reverts the instance
task_state back to None.

It also adds a test_state_revert() test to verify that all the actions
marked for state reversion do the right thing. The new
test_no_revert_bad_state() test verifies that the decorator doesn't
arbitrarily revert any task_state.

Note that the existing admin password test was checking that the
task_state remained unmodified after failure, which is no longer
the expected or desired behavior.

Fixes bug 1025722

Change-Id: Id4358c508156c713cb953dfa0f01a6f598bc1e7d

commit_message:
Revert task_state on failed instance actions

Right now, the task_state logic in compute/api.py can be broken, such
that instances can get stuck in an uneditable state if an action is
performed that fails. The task_state remains something like 'stopping'
even though the action has not been completed or queued, and further
requests that depend on task_state will fail (see check_instance_state()
in compute/apy.py).

The only way out of it is to delete the instance or hack the database.

This patch adds a reverts_task_state() decorator to compute/manager.py,
which, upon operation failure, reverts the instance's task_state back
to None.

It also adds a test_state_revert() test to verify that all the actions
marked for state reversion do the right thing. It also corrects several
other tests that specifically expect the task_state to remain after
an error has occurred.

Fixes bug 1025722

Change-Id: Id4358c508156c713cb953dfa0f01a6f598bc1e7d

commit_message:
volumes: fix check_for_export() in non-exporting volume drivers

This overrides the default check_for_export so that drivers that don't
need to export block devices on the host like Sheepdog and RBD don't
raise a NotImplemented exception when this is called.

Change-Id: I9e46f84a2a491f8e1f281b3eea86106147b27976
Reported-by: Mark Moseley <moseleymark@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

commit_message:
Update Getting started to match change to heat-jeos

heat-jeos list will no longer list jeos in the image name.  As a result,
we can't specify "-jeos" in the getting started guide.

Signed-off-by: Steven Dake <sdake@redhat.com>

Couple of comments...

Some of the formatting while correct is kinda ugly/difficult to read IMO.  Would you be interested in cleaning some of these up a bit?  For example the args list on line 518.

More importantly, I'm surprised but I don't see any unit tests for the RBD driver?  It would be great if you could add some unit tests for this.  Unless I'm missing something?"}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2012-08-14 06:00:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm happy to change the formatting. I'm used to the style around line 518 from another project, but I'll gladly change it if that style is less readable here. Would having each option and its value on a different line be clearer, i.e.:

args = [
   'rbd', 'create'
   '--pool', FLAGS.rbd_pool,
   '--image', volume['name'],
   '--size', size,
   ]

or do you prefer the list starting the same line as the brackets?

As for tests, it's true that there are no unit tests for the RBD driver. This is because it's all simple shell calls, with no real logic. I don't really see the value in unit tests that repeat exactly what the code is doing, but maybe you have other tests in mind?

My changes for efficient-volume-from-image will have some unit tests for the RBD driver, since it gains some logic there."}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2012-08-14 15:18:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 15:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-13 22:34:53.000000000', 'message': "rbd: implement create_volume_from_snapshot

In an upcoming release, rbd will support creating volumes from
snapshots ('cloning'). To clone a snapshot, it must first be
'protected', which means it cannot be deleted until it is unprotected.
A snapshot can only be unprotected if no clones depend on it. Thus,
translate a failure to unprotect into a SnapshotIsBusy exception.

Also check for remaining snapshots before deleting a volume,
and raise VolumeIsBusy if any exist.

This is backwards compatible since it does not use the new features
unless they are available in the installed version of rbd.

Change-Id: If4105e7af7ba33f09a15103b53ad675aceb2ebb4
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>
"}, {'created': '2012-08-14 15:18:07.000000000', 'message': "rbd: implement create_volume_from_snapshot

In an upcoming release, rbd will support creating volumes from
snapshots ('cloning'). To clone a snapshot, it must first be
'protected', which means it cannot be deleted until it is unprotected.
A snapshot can only be unprotected if no clones depend on it. Thus,
translate a failure to unprotect into a SnapshotIsBusy exception.

Also check for remaining snapshots before deleting a volume,
and raise VolumeIsBusy if any exist. While we're here, tidy up
the shell arguments to be more readable.

This is backwards compatible since it does not use the new features
unless they are available in the installed version of rbd.

Change-Id: If4105e7af7ba33f09a15103b53ad675aceb2ebb4
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>
"}]
commit_message:
rbd: implement create_volume_from_snapshot

In an upcoming release, rbd will support creating volumes from
snapshots ('cloning'). To clone a snapshot, it must first be
'protected', which means it cannot be deleted until it is unprotected.
A snapshot can only be unprotected if no clones depend on it. Thus,
translate a failure to unprotect into a SnapshotIsBusy exception.

Also check for remaining snapshots before deleting a volume,
and raise VolumeIsBusy if any exist. While we're here, tidy up
the shell arguments to be more readable.

This is backwards compatible since it does not use the new features
unless they are available in the installed version of rbd.

Change-Id: If4105e7af7ba33f09a15103b53ad675aceb2ebb4
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

commit_message:
Replace deprecated client with python-glanceclient

This is a copy of the code that was merged into Nova.
python-glanceclient is required for Folsom, and for using
the v2 API.

Implementing blueprint efficient-volumes-from-images
requires this since it needs to access the v2 API.

Change-Id: Ia088517abab61e824a641d4adf616e08a53a94bc

commit_message:
Fix visual indentation for PEP8 conformance.

Corrects misindented continuations (PEP8 E127, E128).

The run_tests.sh script's PEP8 pass (with current 1.3.3) was
reporting under- or over-indented visual continuations in a handful
of files, all of which are fixed with this trivial patch.

Change-Id: I19388dc0011546abe65b37d31df02debb3676003

state. This is to update the diagram in devref doc.

Hi Gary,
I add an check_env method on quota ext so that it can check the quota driver if it is right. If the quota driver is not one needed, the extension will refuse to be loaded.
The quota per tenant is a sample resource extension, which exposes a new resource, can check the env to decide if it can be loaded, all the files are residing in extension folders, etc. All these fit in extension framework change.

obviously, the quantum commands quotas-xx will fail if the quota extension is not loaded. I think we can enhance the quantum commands quota-xx to call the ext-xx api, and then call the quotas extension api, which I can introduce in a new change.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-14 15:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

[{'created': '2012-08-14 15:45:08.000000000', 'message': "Add quota per-tenant.

blueprint quantum-api-quotas

We implement it as an extension for linux bridge and ovs plugins.
We also expose the /quotas/Xx url to client to operate the quota.
We need admin role to show other tenant's quota, and to update quota data.
Any user can show its own tenant's quota. An DB table is used to save the
quota for each tenant.

To use it, we have in quantum.conf:
quota_driver = quantum.extensions._quotav2_driver.DbQuotaDriver

The default quotas for each tenant are defined in quantum.conf too.

In addition, modify extension framework to allow exposing a new resource and
its controler. The extension can check the environment, such as configuration
in global cfg.CONF to decide if it can be enabled.

Also, we can define enabled extensions for each plugin in extensions.py
New resources can be put into quota framework via quota_items in nova.conf

Change-Id: I54d6107fdb2808cdae1a40b501ed8c7f379dedee

commit_message:
Add quota per-tenant.

blueprint quantum-api-quotas

We implement it as an extension for linux bridge and ovs plugins.
We also expose the /quotas/Xx url to client to operate the quota.
We need admin role to show other tenant's quota, and to update quota data.
Any user can show its own tenant's quota. An DB table is used to save the
quota for each tenant.

To use it, we have in quantum.conf:
quota_driver = quantum.extensions._quotav2_driver.DbQuotaDriver

The default quotas for each tenant are defined in quantum.conf too.

In addition, modify extension framework to allow exposing a new resource and
its controler. The extension can check the environment, such as configuration
in global cfg.CONF to decide if it can be enabled.

Also, we can define enabled extensions for each plugin in extensions.py
New resources can be put into quota framework via quota_items in nova.conf

Change-Id: I54d6107fdb2808cdae1a40b501ed8c7f379dedee

commit_message:
Validate that min_count & max_count parameters are numeric.

Changed nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py to include
validation of min_count and max_count. min_count and max_count
must be numeric values >=1 and min_count must be <= max_count.
Also, added tests to test_servers.py to verify these restrictions.

Fixes: bug #1035482
Change-Id: I530c11b683a905ee67f679ef485c9f7669f1e074

commit_message:
nova-api-metadata

You can run the nova-api-metadata service instead of running
nova-api if the compute hosts are not API endpoints. This simplifies
configuration.

Cherry picked from https://review.openstack.org/11226

Change-Id: Ic60ffe53070ab2c7ac2ddd8d30ea50d216fcbe42

commit_message:
heat api : bugfix, save config correctly in EC2Token

Fix issue where EC2Token fails to save the config correctly,
which breaks AWS Authentication

Fixes #191

Change-Id: I77dfe182aac81c55b7d487d88073b40eac1faadd
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

subject: Clear task state in case of error during execution
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1711, 'name': 'Yun Mao', 'email': 'yunmao@gmail.com', 'username': 'yunmao'}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 4922, 'name': 'linlin-cqu', 'email': 'linlin.cqu@gmail.com', 'username': 'linlin-cqu'}]

looks good. Saving +2 until someone from ozone can verify that this isn't going to cause problems for them."}, {'account_id': 4922, 'date': '2012-08-05 01:43:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-08-06 14:25:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This fixes bug 1025722'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-06 18:31:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Leaving task_state set when an instance is set to ERROR is the intended behavior. See commit  041e325dd03cbe5874770708f8e3f2b4a73d756c for more information.

I'm not sure I understand how a snapshot failure can leave the task_state set. Commit b69e89f60c635f1e0fb5e25696e3b5ad26416b56 added code to ensure it gets cleared. I guess the idea being that a snapshot failure shouldn't move the instance to ERROR since it's still running fine.

Couldn't we do the same thing for other code which don't correctly reset task_state when the instance is still running fine?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-08-06 19:09:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Well, task_state has to be cleaned up in at least a few cases, otherwise the instance gets stuck.

For example, if you do "nova stop foo" and it fails, task_state will be "stopping". You can't issue another stop or a new reboot command because of the task_state prereq in api.py, nor a start because of the vm_state prereq, etc.

In a previous (now abandoned because of this change) review, I had proposed a new decorator be added to those actions which do require task_state reversion. Perhaps that would be a better path than doing it implicitly everywhere?'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-06 19:19:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd be all for something a bit more generic than sprinkling the code with try/except or try/finally blocks. Especially since state transitions have been a constant source of bugs and pain in the code.

It can only be so generic because of some of the more complicated uses of state transitions (see resizes)."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-08-06 19:43:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yun,

Would it be okay for me to resurrect my task_state decorator patch (minus all the lock stuff we split out as part of the review) and re-propose it for Johannes and you to look at?'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-08-06 19:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Johannes,

the VM state management has been re-designed since the commit you mentioned. See http://wiki.openstack.org/VMState and commit 129b87e17d3333aeaa9e855a70dea51e6581ea63. Now task_state is the indicator of a ongoing task running. When the task finishes, it should no longer be set. The resize case was specially treated before this but it has been taken care of by introducing the RESIZED state in the vm state machine. Now when an error occurs, there is no need to do task-specific handing on task_state.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-06 20:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yun, you're correct in that it is simpler now after the recent changes, but it's still a bit complicated with how task_state changes occur in different methods at different times.

It's hard to audit the code as it is now and say "yes, state changes occur correctly in both normal and error cases".

I'm certainly a fan of the work that has gone into cleaning up the state management, but I feel like we can still do more.

That may or may not be out of scope for this patch.'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-08-07 00:55:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Johannes,

I think we are very much in agreement here. :)

After the vm state machine cleanup, the task state should always be None. Now the error cases and the regular cases are dealt separately. This patch only fixes the error cases. It's probably cleaner to reset task state to None in a single location (in the spirit of a try.. finally block), for auditing purpose at least. However, I did not do that because it's a refactoring + a bug fix, which sometimes is frowned upon. It may also introduce an extra db operation as right now for successful cases vm_state and task_state are likely to be updated together in one db API call. So I'm not exactly sure if everyone is ok with that."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-08-09 16:42:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Failures during tasks like snapshot and update_admin_password are in someways different from a failure in say rebuild because the end result is still a running VM - hence although the task state needs to be cleared the vm_state can't got to error as a) its confusing and b) the only recovery a user would have is a delete/rebuid/reboot, none of which are needed.  

I think what's missing here is a new set of instance attributes to provide the user with the status of the last action:  

- last_action  (e.g. rebuild, reboot, snapshot) - only set when the compute manager starts on the action
- last_action_starttime (time started)
- last_action_endtime (time ended)
- last_action_result (one of "Inprogress" (could be qualified by task_state, e.g. "InProgress-Networking"),  "Succeeded", "Failed"
- pending_action (e.g. rebuild, reboot, snapshot) - set when a request is accepted in the API.   This could then also be used to further gate what other actions will be accepted.   

We could of course make these new attributes visible to users via another API extension :-)'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-08-14 09:23:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This and Id4358c508156c713cb953dfa0f01a6f598bc1e7d are roughly equivalent, except that by using @wrap_instance_fault we are reverting task_state during operations for which we don't set task_state in the first place

e.g. if get_diagnostics() fails, why unset task_state?

So, I think we should go with the @reverts_task_state approach"}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-08-14 14:02:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

@markmc: agreed.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-03 15:18:48.000000000', 'message': 'Clear task state in case of error during execution

When a task such as snapshot, update_admin_passwd fails with an
exception, task_state is not cleared so that it blocks other APIs
from being called upon the instance, except for delete. This patch
makes sure that task_state is cleared in case of a exception is
thrown. If the task is finished without an exception, the task
state is set to None already. A couple of tests are fixed too.

Part of bp task-management

Change-Id: I17d6c3b15c59ce0e8cf5dff2191b46687a17dba7
'}]
commit_message:
Clear task state in case of error during execution

When a task such as snapshot, update_admin_passwd fails with an
exception, task_state is not cleared so that it blocks other APIs
from being called upon the instance, except for delete. This patch
makes sure that task_state is cleared in case of a exception is
thrown. If the task is finished without an exception, the task
state is set to None already. A couple of tests are fixed too.

Part of bp task-management

Change-Id: I17d6c3b15c59ce0e8cf5dff2191b46687a17dba7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-08 13:11:15.000000000', 'message': 'Enforce quota limitations for instance resize.

Fixes LP 1030010.

Close off a back-door allowing users to go over-quota on
instances, ram and/or cores by creating a tiny instance
and then resizing to any size regardless of the reminaing
usage headroom.

The quota management logic is distributed in the sense that
the reservations are passed with the RPC casts that may fail
silently, so that the rollback or commit is handled by the
actor finalizing the resize/confirmation/reversion.

Up-sizing requires there is sufficient quota headroom upfront
for the larger size, whereas conversely down-sizing only
results in a usage reduction when the resize is confirmed.

Change-Id: I2b1cbb098c79e37d7ad19221fe23657eb018eae6

commit_message:
Enforce quota limitations for instance resize.

Fixes LP 1030010.

Close off a back-door allowing users to go over-quota on ram
and/or cores by creating a tiny instance and then resizing
to any size regardless of the remaining usage headroom.

The quota management logic is distributed in the sense that
the reservations are passed with the RPC casts that may fail
silently, so that the rollback or commit is handled by the
actor finalizing the resize/confirmation/reversion.

Up-sizing requires there is sufficient quota headroom upfront
to accommodate the larger size, whereas conversely down-sizing
only results in a usage reduction when the resize is confirmed.

Change-Id: I2b1cbb098c79e37d7ad19221fe23657eb018eae6

I would prefer to see the volume created at the same time, as it seems a redundant step to first create and then initialize with the image. It's also prone to over-writing the wrong volume.

What do others think..?"}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2012-08-09 18:37:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for addressing all the comments from yesterday.

I agree with Dermot, making it create instead of copy to an existing volume would be less error prone. It would also make the efficient-create-from-volume blueprint make more sense, since it wouldn't have to remove the existing volume to create a copy-on-write clone of an image, for example."}, {'account_id': 1633, 'date': '2012-08-10 07:22:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think the requirement to create a fresh volume before calling the copy-image-onto-volume extension is an implicit expectation from the user.
I also think this will promote efficient utilization of volumes, by allowing the user to re-use an existing Volume, and not have the overhead of creating a new volume for copy-image.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2012-08-10 07:51:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

If the api is 'copy image to volume', then yes, the user would expect to use an existing one. But Dermot and I are suggesting that the api be 'create image from volume' for the reasons above.

I don't see where there's much overhead in creating a new volume. That should be a fast operation compared to filling it with data. I think most volume drivers support thin provisioning as well, if you're really worried about the extra time to create a volume."}, {'account_id': 1633, 'date': '2012-08-11 06:11:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

I am working on the extension changes (creating a new volume and copying image onto it).'}, {'account_id': 1633, 'date': '2012-08-11 17:34:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-11 17:45:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Adds new volume API extensions

Adds following extensions:
1. Create volume from image
2. Copy volume to image

Added unit tests.

Implements: blueprint create-volume-from-image
Change-Id: I9c73bd3fa2fa2e0648c01ff3f4fc66f757d7bc3f

overall, I think this looks good.  we obviously need unit tests for the new DB entities.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Unit tests and a bit of cleanup are still needed on the linuxbridge plugin implementation. The linuxbridge agent implementation and the openvswitch plugin and agent implementations will be ready soon, but quick feedback on this patch set is more than welcome.

A couple questions:

Should the provider property names (and DB column names, variable names, etc.) be shortened from network_type to net_type and from physical_network to phys_net?

Should the provider:physical_network default to a value such as "default" so it doesn't need to be specified when their is only one physical network?'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

New patch set coming up with linuxbridge agent, and some comments addressed.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (10 inline comments)

See my replies to the in-line comments. An updated patch set that includes the linuxbridge agent should be ready later today.

Any feedback on the attribute names or on whether requiring provider:network_type is OK, or whether passing provider:vlan_id <vlan-id> should work alone?'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

Hi Bob,

some initials comments and questions pending a more thorough review.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Bob,

Could you outline what work is left here before this goes from WIP to a full review?  OVS support, but anything else?'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Hi,
It looks like the RPC support is missing. In addition to this there is something that I do not understand and maybe an example would clarify. Say we have 2 hosts running the linux bridge agent A and B. On A say there are 2 interface em1 and em2. On B There are there interface eth0 eth1 and eth2. It is not clear from the code that emx and ethx will be used and what the mappings are. I am not sure if this is handled in the scope of this patch.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

Responses to Salvatore's comments."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

The linuxbridge agent now supports multiple physical interfaces for vlans and for flat networks. It no longer supports V1.

The next update will include unit tests for l2network_db_v2 and removal of all V1 code from linuxbridge, and will hopefully be ready to merge.

The openvswitch plugin will be updated as a third phase via a separate patch set.

Please get your comments in as soon as possible.

Thanks,

-Bob'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

Dan,

I plan to submit a new patch set today with the linuxbridge DB unit tests added, the V1 linuxbridge code removed, various review comments addressed, and a bit of my own cleanup. I will now also need to rebase and update the agent due to Gary's linuxbridge RPC changes.

My plan is to submit that patch set for (hopefully quick) approval (not WIP), and to follow-up with a separate patch set for the openvswitch plugin by Monday.

I'm leaning towards switching from MultiStrOpts to ListOpts for the two config variables in this patch set. Any issue with that?

I'm also planning to leave the naming and usage of the provider attributes as-is in this patch set unless I get some quick feedback that it needs to change.

-Bob"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Nachi,

That is the intent. Flat networks just normal networks with no VLAN tag, no tunneling, etc.  Can you suggest a better name?

-Bob'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/1183/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-docs/434/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/1054/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/823/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/824/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (16 inline comments)

Hi,
Please see my inline comments.

I ran into issues with nova boot --nic which I do not think are related to this patch. I worked around that by creating a flat network in devstack. The ssh connection to devstack was terminated.

All connectivity from the host to the outside world was lost. This should be investigated.

Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (14 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The phase 2 implementation of the provider-networks BP for linuxbridge is ready for review and hopefully merging.

The corresponding devstack patch to properly configure the linuxbridge physical interface is at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/11262/.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/844/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/845/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (10 inline comments)

Some more comments from me, along the same lines as Dan's"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (12 inline comments)

overall, looks good.  A far number of style suggestions as well as a couple things that may actually be issues.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (14 inline comments)

Please see my responses to the comments in-line. Overall, I didn't see any comments that should absolutely prevent merging this patch set as is. Some additional cleanup can be done in the phase 3 patch I'm working on now. Please let me know if you feel this patch set has to be revised before it can be merged. I think the time would be much better spent working on phase 3."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Gary's comments have been mostly addressed, and its rebased as of the bulk create commit. The metaplugin commit should not conflict.

The linuxbridge and openvswitch unit tests should now all work, since the unit tests are now configured to use the kombu_fake RPC backend.

When using devstack, don't forget to apply https://review.openstack.org/#/c/11262/.

There are two known issues for which I plan to file bugs and defer fixing until after this patch is committed:

1) If you create a quantum flat network using a host physical_interface that has an IP address, connectivity on that interface will be lost. Flat networks can be tested by configuring the host with a 2nd NIC. This issue will be fixed later by moving the IP from the physical_interface to the bridge.

2) Missing physical_interfaces are not handled very well by the agent if a port is created on the corresponding physical_network.

I believe these two issues can be easily addressed during the Folsom bug fixing phase, and its more critical to get both this patch and the upcoming openvswitch patch in for the F-3 milestone tomorrow.

-Bob"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (8 inline comments)

Had to rebase again, so addressed most comments in upcoming patch set. See in-line dispositions for the comments here.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/874/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/875/consoleFull : SUCCESS

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

i'm +2-ing this, based on previous conversation with Bob that there is a final patch coming tomorrow that will fix up a couple of issues.  

Gary, unclear if you wanted the branch held up still, so I'm not approving.  Feel free to approve, or we can wait to have Salvatore look at it as he should be online."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Hi,
I have approved. Only concern that I have is the flat networks and I think that a bug should be opened for that one.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(4 inline comments)

Hi,
Some minor comments inline.
When running things out of the box they work fine. 
I have problems with the flat networks. I am still testing.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Had to rebase, so addressed most of the comments from the previous patch set as well:

- FLAT_VLAN_ID = -1

- physical_interface_mappings not used in server, all physical_network names are now defined via network_vlan_ranges.

- better error handling parsing configuration variables

- moved is_attr_set to attributes.py

- simplified l2networks_db_v2.release_network

- enabled native bulk operarations'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Hi Bob
For me, definition of Flat network is not clear.
It reminds me FlatManager in Nova..'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Hi Bob.

I got it. It would be helpful if we have comment which discribes
--provider:network_type'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'message': "Implementation of second phase of provider extension.

Enhances provider extension to support flat networks and VLANs on
multiple physical networks. Implements blueprint provider-networks.

To create a flat network using the CLI with admin rights:

net-create --tenant_id <tenant-id> <net-name> --provider:network_type flat --provider:physical_network <physical-network>

To create a VLAN network using the CLI with admin rights:

net-create --tenant_id <tenant-id> <net-name> --provider:network_type vlan --provider:physical_network <physical-network> --provider:vlan_id <vlan-id>

The provider extension is supported by the linuxbridge and openvswitch
plugins and their agents [openvswitch phase 2 implementation is
in-progress, and does not yet support flat networks or multiple
interfaces].

Ranges of VLANs available on named physical networks for normal
allocation are specified in the plugin's config file via the
ListOpt syntax:

network_vlan_ranges = <physical_network>:<vlan_min>:<vlan_max>

The mapping of each named physical network to its physical network
interface is specified (per-agent-host) in the agent's config file via
the ListOpt syntax:

physical_interface_mappings = <physical_network>:<physical_interface>

Change-Id: I93402bd5cc6316e9408ea71c3b3989d06898ee30
"}, {'created': '2012-08-14 10:45:50.000000000', 'message': "Implementation of second phase of provider extension.

The provider extension is supported by the linuxbridge and openvswitch

The mapping of each named physical network to its physical network

the MultiStrOpt syntax:

physical_interface_mappings = <physical_network>:<physical_interface>

net-create --tenant_id <tenant-id> <net-name> --provider:network_type flat --provider:physical_network <physical-network>

To create a VLAN network using the CLI with admin rights:

net-create --tenant_id <tenant-id> <net-name> --provider:network_type vlan --provider:physical_network <physical-network> --provider:vlan_id <vlan-id>

The provider extension is supported by the linuxbridge and openvswitch
plugins and their agents [openvswitch phase 2 implementation is
in-progress, and does not yet support flat networks or multiple
interfaces].

Ranges of VLANs available on named physical networks for normal
allocation are specified in the plugin's config file via the
ListOpt syntax:

network_vlan_ranges = <physical_network>:<vlan_min>:<vlan_max>

The mapping of each named physical network to its physical network
interface is specified (per-agent-host) in the agent's config file via
the ListOpt syntax:

physical_interface_mappings = <physical_network>:<physical_interface>

See quantum/plugins/linuxbridge/README for details and examples of
network_vlan_ranges and physical_interface_mappings usage.

Also, bulk operations are enabled for the linuxbridge plugin.

Change-Id: I93402bd5cc6316e9408ea71c3b3989d06898ee30

commit_message:
Implementation of second phase of provider extension.

Enhances provider extension to support flat networks and VLANs on
multiple physical networks. Implements blueprint provider-networks.

To create a flat network using the CLI with admin rights:

net-create --tenant_id <tenant-id> <net-name> --provider:network_type flat --provider:physical_network <physical-network>

To create a VLAN network using the CLI with admin rights:

net-create --tenant_id <tenant-id> <net-name> --provider:network_type vlan --provider:physical_network <physical-network> --provider:vlan_id <vlan-id>

The provider extension is supported by the linuxbridge and openvswitch
plugins and their agents [openvswitch phase 2 implementation is
in-progress, and does not yet support flat networks or multiple
interfaces].

Ranges of VLANs available on named physical networks for normal
allocation are specified in the plugin's config file via the
ListOpt syntax:

network_vlan_ranges = <physical_network>:<vlan_min>:<vlan_max>

The mapping of each named physical network to its physical network
interface is specified (per-agent-host) in the agent's config file via
the ListOpt syntax:

physical_interface_mappings = <physical_network>:<physical_interface>

See quantum/plugins/linuxbridge/README for details and examples of
network_vlan_ranges and physical_interface_mappings usage.

Also, bulk operations are enabled for the linuxbridge plugin.

Change-Id: I93402bd5cc6316e9408ea71c3b3989d06898ee30

commit_message:
Xen API version check fix

Fixes bug 1033933.

Xenapi driver raised an error while extracting version information.
Version information check is required to detect the proper VDI resize
command. The fix falls back to VDI.resize, if some part of the version
information is missing.

Change-Id: I444437a40ed5b803898c6e1c0cc1821c984c1403

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove deprecated boot=on kvm flag.

Stop passing boot=on when invoking kvm manually, as this parameter
has been deprecated and is ignored.

Change-Id: Ifd7c4607f8101868ab99ac5c80b0c040983fc18b

[{'created': '2012-08-14 08:25:04.000000000', 'message': 'deal with parent_id not in target.

bug 1036425

commit_message:
deal with parent_id not in target.

bug 1036425

If we filter the fields of the requested resource, we have no parent_id in the target, which we must be tolerant with.

Change-Id: Ieb591d9208f16a0d3e05bda00bf45ae7aca846a5

Support --no-gateway option

if --no-gateway is specified, null is used for gateway value.
Fixs bug 1035987

commit_message:
Fixed validation check for ICMP rules

Fixed the code that checks the ICMP type/code
as from/to ports. Also fixed the CSS for the
security rules form, and the script to change
the form labels in case of form reload due to
an error.

Fixes bug 997669

Change-Id: I3b9c0ba3f46b91a311f887560dae5e9399961b84
(cherry picked from commit 7b565fc9839833b4b99b1fc3b02269b79071af3e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-11 22:51:52.000000000', 'message': 'user_name_attribute and tenant_name_attribute LDAP flags

Document new LDAP-related keystone flags that configure how the
keystone user name and tenant name map to LDAP attributes.

commit_message:
user_name_attribute and tenant_name_attribute LDAP flags

Document new LDAP-related keystone flags that configure how the
keystone user name and tenant name map to LDAP attributes.

Documents fix to bug 997700

Patchset fixes a duplicate "and the", adds explanations for the
SN and OU LDAP attributes, and adds a "for example"
for Common Name instead of SurName.

Implemented in keystone by https://review.openstack.org/10544

Change-Id: I3b8620edfa02eafcc7c37dcf2ed22757b985c5be

commit_message:
glance-scrubber.conf does not require db info

Remove database connection options from glance-scrubber.conf.

As of essex, the glance scrubber connects directly to the registry
API, it does not need to hit the database.

See https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/836381

Change-Id: Id08a5b64e84dd62303c928c052542693e190162c

commit_message:
Switch to use python-swiftclient instead of cloudfiles.

This patch also resolves some thread-safety problems
with when the browser and associated tables are constructed
and where the request and data caches are stored on the table.

Also includes stylistic and UX enhancments to the swift
ResourceBrowser subclass.

Implements blueprint swiftclient.

Change-Id: I578277ff158b293ee50860528b069dc20e2136a9

subject: Refreshes keystone token if a token is expired.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-merge/156/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-docs/39/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-pep8/121/consoleFull : FAILURE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-python26/100/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-python27/99/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/7475/consoleFull : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Nachi,

> we should check whether the token is expired or not before request.

I introduced new variable 'token_retrieved' to HTTPClient class
to distinguish the two situation (token expired and before request).

Before the first request self.endpoint_url is None, so a token is
retrieved from keystone before calling quantum API.
Once authorized by keystone, 'endpoint_url' is set to the valid URL and
'token_retrieved' is changed to False to True.

When the token is expired, I detect the token expiration by Unauthorized
(401 status code) from Quantum API. If keystone authN is used
token_retrieved is True at this moment as described above. So I
checked token_retrieved and call authenticate() again to refresh
a token.  I do not use time-based approach to compare the expiration time and the current time.


I don't take care of the case that endpoint_url and token are passed in the constructor.
I think when keystone authN is used username/password should be passed.

Does it make sense for you?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-merge/157/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-docs/40/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-pep8/122/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-python26/101/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-python27/100/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/7479/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Thank you for the review. I replied inline.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Gary,
I am not sure I understand the situation you experienced correctly and it is related to this bug.
Could you explain what you did?

My simple test just changing the envvars works as expected.
http://paste.openstack.org/show/20284/
After I changed the envvars the result was changed and a token is retrieved from keystone whenever quantum command is invoked.
(Sorry if my understanding is wrong)


BTW, this can be reproduced by the following sequence:
(1) Start devstack
(2) Change/Set "expiration = 10" in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf
(3) Restart keystone (Go to keystone window in screen, type Ctrl-C, and rerun the previous command)
(4) Open python interactive shell and execute the following session: http://paste.openstack.org/show/20286/

In the last line [5] is executed, I got Unauthorized exception. At this time, we expects that quantum client refresh the token from keystone.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi,
At times when I am working in a console and I change the environment variables (. openrc or .openrc admin admin). The client behaves the same as the original setting. That is, say I am an admin then I can view the provider network info. If I change to the demo user then I can still view the provider network info.
Have any of you encountered this? Does this patch resolve an issue like this?
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Good Job!
IMO, we should check whether the token is expired or not before request.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I got it. It make sense.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

one comment needs reply. After that I can give +2."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-14 05:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Fix scheduler hint extension to check for missing 'server' attribute
in the body.  Return a HTTP 400. (not 500)

bug 1035356

[{'created': '2012-08-12 09:47:45.000000000', 'message': 'Simplify the sql backend deletion of users and tenants.

There is a remaining problem in that the table definition permits dangling
membership in tenants, and vice verca, but this change will make the fix for
that easier to review, and make the code simpler and faster at the sametime.

See bug 1000609 for the bug report that lead to examining this.

Change-Id: Id7cd5fad7032779d352a7c577c8d10558091d767
'}]
commit_message:
Simplify the sql backend deletion of users and tenants.

There is a remaining problem in that the table definition permits dangling
membership in tenants, and vice verca, but this change will make the fix for
that easier to review, and make the code simpler and faster at the sametime.

See bug 1000609 for the bug report that lead to examining this.

Change-Id: Id7cd5fad7032779d352a7c577c8d10558091d767

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-08-13 17:23:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There is a nasty bug with flavors, but I'm not sure if it is related to this patch. It is related to deleting a flavor. Try this:

1. Create a new flavor with Disk 1GB
2. Create a new instance using this Flavor
3. Delete the flavor.
4. Create new flavor with Disk 3GB

When going to the 'Instances' table, you'll see in the table for the 'Size' column the following: 
....  | 3BG 

But when opening the Instance details page, you see that it has 1GB disk, as expected. So the second flavor is being created with the previous ID, and is being displayed on the Insntace details page instead of the original one..."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-08-13 19:09:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

That's a nova bug, as far as I'm aware. In my testing Nova did not reassign any ID that had been used by any instance in the system. I have a devstack running right now with this patch where the behavior is correct. If you can reproduce it against a specific combination of Nova/Horizon I'd open a separate bug for it."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-08-13 19:10:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

[{'created': '2012-08-12 22:52:17.000000000', 'message': 'Adds faux "edit" UI for Flavors.

Since Nova manages flavors by way of marking flavors as
inactive (to avoid losing data for instances), we want to
"edit" a flavor by first deleting the old flavor and then
adding in a new flavor with the same name but a new id.

Implements blueprint edit-flavor-ui.

Change-Id: If78cc2c6469e6957e766f6b260b6beeaddeeb50e
'}]
commit_message:
Adds faux "edit" UI for Flavors.

Since Nova manages flavors by way of marking flavors as
inactive (to avoid losing data for instances), we want to
"edit" a flavor by first deleting the old flavor and then
adding in a new flavor with the same name but a new id.

Implements blueprint edit-flavor-ui.

Change-Id: If78cc2c6469e6957e766f6b260b6beeaddeeb50e
