commit_message:
Rewrite image code to use python-glanceclient

This patch rewrites the Glance-specific code within Nova to use
the new python-glanceclient library. The old client is deprecated
in Folsom and should not be used in conjunction with
python-glanceclient.

This removes the dependency on installing 'glance' through pip.

Implements bp integrate-python-glanceclient
Fixes bug 880964

Change-Id: Ifb9e75593abd36a2d1c08773d02f192e5e5627fc

commit_message:
improve test_db_plugin so it can be leveraged by extension tests

prereq for bp quantum-l3-fwd-nat

- load extension middleware as well as core API
- support 'action' requests in addition to CRUD ops
- add helper methods that check API return code
- clean-up places where existing tests where hitting 409s on delete
but ignoring the errors (basically SubnetInUse errors).

Change-Id: I620f1ef7f2028879b3b86f90c2150c26aa0f23c1

commit_message:
implementation for bug 1008180

implement the database models for the v2 db plugin base to store dns + additional routes
also handles the dns/route remote/update

commit_message:
Adds i18n support for Javascript.

Uses Django's built-in client-side i18n machinery to
support translation strings in javascript code as well.

Various cleanup, etc. included to make translation file
generation succeed and remove obsolete strings.

Implements blueprint javascript-i18n.

Change-Id: I62c237ae98b26307e1e7d8a7d913237530e7324f

(3 inline comments)

Some minor comments on the code. 

The bigger issue is that the code to actually tie this to the dhcp agent isn't here, so I don't think it makes sense to merge code that implies that the user is able to set the DHCP server, when it is currently just a value in a DB that has no impact on the actual DHCP behavior. 

Also, I think this field always needs to be available on a subnet, not just available only if the user explicitly sets it.  

If we continue to believe this is critical for working with Nova security groups, we'll have to push for a change like this in Folsom.  If we do that though, I would simplify things by making dhcp_ips a single value, and make it a read-only field (i.e., tenants are not able to update)."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 22:07:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 22:07:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Dan

DHCP ip should not be configurable by user. It should be done by service account.
And also if you consider Multi-host or Simple HA ( launch two dhcp-agent ),  one dhcp-server didn't make sense.
I was waiting fix dhcp-agent side change because it looks changing structure. However I can work on this today .

Or, How about this spec?
Just search port which's device_id start with 'dhcp' simply."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 22:07:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Yong 
I updated spec.
Now subnet has dhcp address.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 22:07:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Add device_owner attribute to port

in order for firewall logic to be able to poke a hole allowing traffic to/from a DHCP server,
we need to expose the IP being used for DHCP in a subnet to external entities.
This commit adds device_owner attribute, then dhcp-agent will update the device_owner value
of port to dhcp-agent.

Implement blueprint expose-dhcp-server-ip
Change-Id: I11283485bff8a3a3cf0b1a2716763ad32e43028a

commit_message:
Fix rpc error with live_migration.

The topic argument to live_migration was removed on the manager side in
rpc API version 1.3, but was not removed from scheduler/rpcapi.py.
Remove it now.

Change-Id: I0b1c68848f7bd55f6f10c63b9433746f0a343a63

Dan, it looks like injected_files has been broken in xenapi for a while.

I've pushed up a new version that fixes that bug. I'm working on a followup patch to ensure that we unit test injected_files in the future."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:56:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Johannes:

Actually. The code before was broken... but appears to have worked. (Torpedo verifies this)

The most recent patchet appears to have resolved the issue with injected_files in patchset 1.

Looks good to me otherwise.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-13 17:14:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I should have said it's partially broken. It'll work for some inputs, but not for others.

In particular, if the data passed in is a string, it'll decode it as JSON, then throw away the results and try to use the original string.

If the data passed in is a list, then it'll work fine.

Looking closer, I'm not even sure it's necessary to decode a string. That should already happen by this point, and libvirt doesn't do the optional extra json decode.

Either way, that's unrelated to this patch and I'll figure it out and get a patch proposed to test injected_files on xenapi and either remove that extra code or make it consistent across all drivers.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-08-13 21:45:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

[{'created': '2012-08-13 16:13:24.000000000', 'message': "Don't stuff non-db data into instance dict

calling the driver API, those values get stuffed into the instance dict
which is otherwise all data that is stored in the database. This has

Change-Id: I09a7de8eca3791a5ab27e93b22e5ccccee31cf09
"}, {'created': '2012-08-13 16:42:41.000000000', 'message': "Don't stuff non-db data into instance dict

The RPC API passes admin_pass and injected_files as arguments, but when

commit_message:
Don't stuff non-db data into instance dict

The RPC API passes admin_pass and injected_files as arguments, but when
calling the driver API, those values get stuffed into the instance dict
which is otherwise all data that is stored in the database. This has
led to some bugs (such as 1034948) which could have been avoided if
the code was consistent.

Change-Id: I09a7de8eca3791a5ab27e93b22e5ccccee31cf09

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-09 22:58:53.000000000', 'message': "Fix TypeError conversion in API layer

Fix conversion of TypeError to Fault in ResourceExceptionHandler.
TypeError can result when the list of extensions is inovked if the
parameters don't match the extension method's signature.

Specifically, if an empty body was sent with an HTTP POST to create a
server, a 500 error was returned.  This change is a fix to properly
return a 400 instead.

(In Python2.6, the ex_value argument of __exit__ is type string when
ex_type is a TypeError, which caused the conversion logic to get
skipped.)

bug 1035120

Change-Id: I96ad335a6338523345d28b7e744dbc7449b4753d

commit_message:
Fix TypeError conversion in API layer

Fix conversion of TypeError to Fault in ResourceExceptionHandler.
TypeError can result when the list of extensions is inovked if the
parameters don't match the extension method's signature.

Specifically, if an empty body was sent with an HTTP POST to create a
server, a 500 error was returned.  This change is a fix to properly
return a 400 instead.

(In Python2.6, the ex_value argument of __exit__ is type string when
ex_type is a TypeError, which caused the conversion logic to get
skipped.)

bug 1035120

Change-Id: I96ad335a6338523345d28b7e744dbc7449b4753d

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I too think we shouldn't allow for too many ways for specifying that a subnet should have no gateway. In particular "0.0.0.0" and "::" are even more confusing as they might be misinterpreted.

As regards NULL or "none", I don't feel strongly here. Dan's has a good point about XML, so we should probably go with none. I would avoid, if possible, the empty string.

If I were to choose, I'd say that by default the subnet should have no gateway; when we want Quantum to choose a gateway for us, we could use gateway_ip: 'default' in the API. However, I understand it's too late to introduce this kind of discussion, so please just ignore it. 

Nachi is mentioning something concerning another API we should be consistent with. What are you referring to?'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Hi,
There is a bug with the _allocate_pools_for_subnet. If the gateway is None then the allocation pool is still updated.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

> Gary
Could you share why it is bug?

> Salvatore
This parameter list should take none also.

fixed_ips
allocation_pools 
host_routes
dns_nameservers

>All 
OK. So conclusion is use only none ?'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Dan
Thank you for your review.

+1 for only use null because of KISS rule.
I have another thought about API consistency,
the other API may take null but currently it is not implemented.
We should agree basic spec of each API.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

glad that you're working on this.  agree with yong's comments, and also have some minor suggestions about unit tests."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

As a conclusion of IRC meeting, I updated code.
Now it only takes null value.

NOTE.
python-quantumclient need to be updated also.
Because current quantumclient can't take null.
I'll fix client too after this is merged.

Example.
ubuntu@ubuntu:~/devstack$ quantum subnet-create --gateway null 38ea471d-7081-4fd7-b2c4-d2f8a25ac60f 192.168.200.0/24
ERROR: cliff.app Invalid input for gateway_ip. Reason: null is not a valid IP address."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

>Salvatore
NP Thank you for your review

>Yong
This is because client send null as "null"  ( string).
So Json looks like {'gateway_ip':'null'}
This should  be  {'gateway_ip':null}
This is why we should fix client side.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Works for me

Nachi's point is a good one that for a field that is an IP, there is no way the string "null" would be a valid input on the CLI, so we could just covert there.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

Hi Nachi,

Can you respond to the comment inline.  Also, can you file a bug to track updating the CLI to handle "null"?  Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

2 null'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

Hi Dan
Thanks
So the what's the final spec?

1) [] null ""
2) null
3) [] null "null"

?'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Hi Dan
Now I understand your point.
I have made silly misunderstandings.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Yong, Dan
Thank you for your reivews.

Quantum uses json module.
json module translate null in Json to None.

>>> import json
>>> json.loads('{"key":null}')
{u'key': None}

>>> json.loads('{"key":"null"}')
{u'key': u'null'}  <-- This is what the client doing.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

OK if so 

if data != "" and not data:

make sense for you?'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Hi Yong

json null is simplest way. It is good to follow KISS law.
For this api, there are no need to specify 'null' (type string), so it is OK to convert 'null' to null in client side.
This is a also conclusion of  IRC meeting."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/1127/consoleFull : SUCCESS

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/768/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

This patch is almost OK from the API  perspective:

I create a subnet without a gateway with CURL. Req body is:
{"subnet": {"network_id": "b6390d9c-e424-47df-824b-7b49a4b7bf64", "ip_version": 4, "cidr": "10.1.2.0/24", "gateway_ip": null}}

Response is:

{"subnets": [{"name": "", "enable_dhcp": true, "network_id": "b6390d9c-e424-47df-824b-7b49a4b7bf64", "tenant_id": "00dde27a895442aca56f4abf6205006a", "allocation_pools": [{"start": "10.1.2.1", "end": "10.1.2.254"}], "gateway_ip": null, "ip_version": 4, "cidr": "10.1.2.0/24", "id": "0ffb33b7-bb2c-4c39-ab87-5f3836c3c9cc"}]}

I have two comments:
1) the allocation pool takes the whole CIDR range, but we still need an address for the DHCP server IMHO, unless dhcp_enable=False
 2) [minor]instead of returning gateway_ip:null in responses I would prefer that gateway_ip is not set at all. 

I'm also having issues with the dhcp_agent on subnets without gateway.  I don't know whether dhcp_agent updates are out of scope, and probably after all the problem is just me doing something silly.

After I create the subnet, I see the dhcp port and the dnsmasq instance. Host file for dnsmasq is Ok, whereas I am not sure about options:

tag:tag0,option:router,None

Also, the dhcp port has no fixed_ip associated.

VMs do not get IP addresses, their DHCP request expires.

I'd like to hear your view on the above comments. I'm not giving a -1, as I don't know whether such comments are relevant to this patch, and whether the problem I'm having are not just because of my environment.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

I am +2 based on the fact that my comments have been addressed.

Nachi, I have not seen a bug filed about the CLI supporting this.  Is there one?'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

yes, we won't be able to test this until the client is updated."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Could you update the API v2 spec on Wiki to keep the document up-to-date?
http://wiki.openstack.org/Quantum/APIv2-specification'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I got it.
http://wiki.openstack.org/Quantum/APIv2-specification#preview

# I'm very exited cool spec page!"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Hi Dan
Sorry. I filed the bug 
https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/1035987'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

From my (limited) knwoledge it seems it is behaving as option:router was not specified at all, falling back to the default mechanism of using dnsmasq's address as default gw.

What if in the option file we just have:

option:router

instead of

option:router, None"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Hi Salvatore
Thank you for your review! 

1) the allocation pool takes the whole CIDR range, but we still need an address for the DHCP server IMHO, unless dhcp_enable=False

Current, dhcp-agent will get port with auto-assigned IP from allocation pool.
So it is OK to take whole CIDR range by default when gateway_ip=Null.
IMO, we should be able to specify ips which is used by dhcp-agent, but this should be go to another patch.

 2) [minor]instead of returning gateway_ip:null in responses I would prefer that gateway_ip is not set at all. 
Fixed'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

HI Salvatore ,Aaron 

Sorry I missed to mention this.

Dan splited the dhcp part fix as another bug. https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/1028647

So I will work on this in another patch.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Good stuff.  One thing I found in testing.  You need to update 
quantum/agent/linux/dhcp.py so that it will skip writing the gateway option for subnets without gateways. 

Line 245 needs to read:

elif subnet.gateway_ip:'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I missed that bug.  Thanks for pointing it out.

Good work on this change.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think we should support quantum subnet-update --gateway_ip=None too.
Also we should recognize the none, empty string and None as the same.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

hi,
we should use quanum subnet-create netid cidr --gateway_ip=, which can simulate the empty string.
There is a mismatch between the server's mode and client's argument gateway here."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

There is a query comment, but it is not related to this change. It it is true, we should add another change to deal with it.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Python has no null, We just have None.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

regarding your:
Example. ubuntu@ubuntu:~/devstack$ quantum subnet-create --gateway null 38ea471d-7081-4fd7-b2c4-d2f8a25ac60f 192.168.200.0/24 ERROR: cliff.app Invalid input for gateway_ip. Reason: null is not a valid IP address.

I think it is from server side."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

helo, can we use the empty string on the side of client, convert it into None on the server side? After all, client command cannot differentiate null and 'null' from command line.
the command line 'quantum subnet-create|update myname --gateway_ip=null' seems strange. Also for command line parser, the values are always string. Instead, 'quantum  subnet-create|update myname --gateway_ip=' smells better since lots of most of time, we can use 'gateway=' to unset the variable in some script env.

using empty string or None itself as None value on the server side will help cli development. Imagine, if we have another field on server side needs None value, how do we do this? we update the quantum client again?"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

My opinion is:
On the server side, we treat empty string and None itself as None.
So that We don't need to modify our cli command since we can use --gateway_ip= to pass in empty string to server.
and Other application can pass in None itself in Json too.

After that, if any more attribute needs the None value, we don't need to modify the quantum client."}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Hi Nachi, in that case I'll +2 thanks!"}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Hi, I'm trying to test this out. When I have gateway=NULL the following gets put into: /opt/stack/data/dhcp/837be21c-512b-4a79-8854-2833059a587a/opts 

"tag:tag0,option:router,None"

now in the vm if I delete the default gateway and ifconfig eth0 0.0.0.0;  When I do udhcpc eth0; for some reason the vm gets a default gateway address now of 10.0.0.2 (the dhcp server?) 

Can anyone also confirm this?'}, {'account_id': 4592, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Code looks good and straightforward.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-08-13 20:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

'}]

commit_message:
Make sure that there's a way of creating a subnet without a gateway

Fixes bug 1028646
You can use null for gateway ip.

Change-Id: I969112ad46efa22203db40106d4e35dce1757165

commit_message:
Ignore duplicate tags in v2 API

* Creating/updating an image with duplicate tags should result in
  only a single instance of that tag being added
* Attempting to explicitly tag an image with a duplicate tag
  should result in no tags being added
* Fixes bug 1035961

Change-Id: Ie16091f046de98914aea1a1a6777773ddc95c615

This overrides the default check_for_export so that drivers that don't
need to export block devices on the host like Sheepdog and RBD don't
raise a NotImplemented exception when this is called.

Reported-by: Mark Moseley <moseleymark@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: Icf72f51904e7bdc368bfaf0a91dd0433ce3b1cf6
"}]
commit_message:
Fix check_for_export() in non-exporting drivers

This overrides the default check_for_export so that drivers that don't
need to export block devices on the host like Sheepdog and RBD don't
raise a NotImplemented exception when this is called.

Reported-by: Mark Moseley <moseleymark@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: Icf72f51904e7bdc368bfaf0a91dd0433ce3b1cf6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-13 08:38:20.000000000', 'message': "Improve bw_usage_update() performance

Fixes bug 1036084

bw_usage_update() most commonly updates rows vs creates rows.  New rows
are only created on the 1st bandwidth update for an instance or when
the audit period rolls over.  This cuts down DB queries to 1 for the
'update' case.

Added bonus:
Remove unused 'import inspect' in compute manager.

Change-Id: Ie5f6c919676046d817b842138dc9d17d1115d3c0
"}, {'created': '2012-08-13 17:01:38.000000000', 'message': "Improve bw_usage_update() performance

Fixes bug 1036084

bw_usage_update() most commonly updates rows vs creates rows.  New rows
are only created on the 1st bandwidth update for an instance or when
the audit period rolls over.  This cuts down DB queries to 1 for the
'update' case.

Added bonus:
Remove unused 'import inspect' in compute manager.

Change-Id: Ie5f6c919676046d817b842138dc9d17d1115d3c0
"}]
commit_message:
Improve bw_usage_update() performance

Fixes bug 1036084

bw_usage_update() most commonly updates rows vs creates rows.  New rows
are only created on the 1st bandwidth update for an instance or when
the audit period rolls over.  This cuts down DB queries to 1 for the
'update' case.

Added bonus:
Remove unused 'import inspect' in compute manager.

Change-Id: Ie5f6c919676046d817b842138dc9d17d1115d3c0

[{'created': '2012-08-13 17:44:23.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid {} and [] as default arguments

Dict and list objects are mutable and are usually the sources of
subtle bugs when used as default arguments. Avoid them.

Change-Id: I5340c7051455a80c4adfab885d89acb46570fa52
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid {} and [] as default arguments

Dict and list objects are mutable and are usually the sources of
subtle bugs when used as default arguments. Avoid them.

Change-Id: I5340c7051455a80c4adfab885d89acb46570fa52

Remove the need for an internal NoneValue class by making the existence
of the 'default' or 'override' keys signify whether a default or
override is set.

Change-Id: Iacf49553df5ba8414307904a3ee334c7b8c55758
"}]
commit_message:
cfg: clean up None value handling

Remove the need for an internal NoneValue class by making the existence
of the 'default' or 'override' keys signify whether a default or
override is set.

Change-Id: Iacf49553df5ba8414307904a3ee334c7b8c55758

update call. This is breaking some clients of this library because

Change-Id: I9ae20a5e4579240c7d5e86316d6d1e927755dbf5

commit_message:
Allow 'deleted' to be passed through image update

The legacy client allowed users to pass 'deleted' through an
update call. This is breaking some clients of this library because
they expect to be be able to still do that.

Fixes bug 1036315

Change-Id: I9ae20a5e4579240c7d5e86316d6d1e927755dbf5

commit_message:
Cast is_public, protected, deleted to bool

To keep a consistent view of an image, is_public, protected, and
deleted need to be cast to a bool when being parsed from headers.

Fix bug 1036299

Change-Id: I2730a0f2d705d26ebc0ba883e99c1caf44d70b51

to the user from the v1 API.

Fixes bug 1036297

commit_message:
Allow v2 images schema properties in create/update

The list of image attributes allowed in image create/update
calls has gotten out of date, so now we build it based on the
schema itself.

Related to bp api-2

commit_message:
Set example key_size to 1024.

Updates the default key_size and config file example to 1024.
Using the previous value of 2048 would cause database truncation
and/or column size errors because the 'id' column isn't big enough
to hold that much data.

Works around LP Bug #1031191.

Change-Id: Ic28bf0945a65fb80a4b610a4de7afa485d09e2bb

subject: Fix bulk create operations and make them atomic.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 452, 'name': 'Somik Behera', 'email': 'somik@nicira.com', 'username': 'somikbehera'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 1689, 'name': 'Robert Kukura', 'email': 'rk@theep.net', 'username': 'rkukura'}, {'_account_id': 2031, 'name': 'Nachi Ueno', 'email': 'nati.ueno@gmail.com', 'username': 'nati-ueno'}, {'_account_id': 2874, 'name': 'yong sheng gong', 'email': 'gong.yongsheng@99cloud.net', 'username': 'gongysh'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/981/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-docs/233/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/853/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/622/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/623/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Note for reviewers:
For adding atomic bulk create support it has been decided to add methods for bulk create to the plugin. These methods however have not been added to QuantumPluginBaseV2; this means that plugins are not supposed to implement them. 
If a plugin does not support bulk create, the native_bulk_support option in the DATABASE section should be set to False. If this option is missing, it is interpreted as it the plugin does not support bulk create.
Even if a plugin does not support bulk create, atomic bulk behavior can still be achieved by setting the allow_bulk quantum config option to True. If allow_bulk is true and native_bulk_support is false, the API layer will emulate the atomic behavior, deleting elements which were already added in case of a failure.

Finally, unit tests which assume the plugin does support atomic bulk create operations are skipped when ran against a plugin which does not support this feature.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/1048/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-docs/300/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/920/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/689/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/690/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

As stated in a previous comment, I agree we should avoid a specific configuration flag for each plugin. 
I have already added explicit methods for bulk operations. 

However, this alone proved to not be enough. Indeed since db_base_plugin was implementing those methods, they were available automatically in derived plugins (ovs, lb, ryu, cisco)  as well, so the API layer thought those plugins supported bulk operations.

Using API extensions (and letting the plugin declare explicitly it supported the 'bulk_create' extension) proved to be unfeasible with the current extension framework, as a scenario in which the functionality for an existing operation is redefined is not supported, and frankly I'm not sure we want to support it.

A potential alternative is to remove the create_<resource>_bulk methods from db_base_plugin, and have the plugin which support bulk operations explicitly define them. This will allow us to remove the configuration flag I believe.

Drawback is that the "native bulk" unit tests would not work anymore with db_base_plugin, so we'll a little bit less coverage on our current gate tests.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Yong,

Thanks for looking at the code.
Please let me know if the plan I am suggesting for addressing your comment works for you.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Bob,

I see your point, but the reason why I did not do this is that this solution implies that a plugin *must* override this property/method for stating it does not support bulk operations.

This would be tantamount to changing the plugin interface. For previous releases of Quantum we decided not to make changes to the plugin interface late in the release cycle. So I decided from the beginning it should not be changed.

If you feel differently, or if you believe we can implement the strategy you are proposing without doing something tantamount to changing the plugin interface, then I'll be happy to do whatever it takes!"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/1121/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-docs/372/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/992/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/761/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/762/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Fails

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/1198/consoleFull : This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.
- gate-quantum-docs : SKIPPED
- gate-quantum-pep8 : SKIPPED
- gate-quantum-python26 : SKIPPED
- gate-quantum-python27 : SKIPPED
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I addressed both reviewer's comment.
 - Yong: we agreed on an approach that was good enough for him although it did not satisfy his initial request.
- Bob: I tried to address your legitimate request using name mangling. There a __native_bulk_support attribute that we check to state whether the plugin supports or not bulk create. In this way we can be sure that an attribute has been specified in a given class, thus avoiding issues with plugins deriving native_bulk_support() from the base plugin. Hope this works for you."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/1200/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-docs/450/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/1070/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/839/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/840/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

+1 overall.

I think this patch however begs the question re atomicy and consistency and now that it has been shown that every plugin is using the DB layer to implement the v2 plugin api, why not get rid of the v2 plugin api (go back to the v1 api), move all the ipam into the api and use transaction/zope.sqlalchemy to support session based transaction/rollback across the board?'}, {'account_id': 452, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

(1 inline comment)

Looks good. API simplification and refactoring seems unrelated to the bugfix changes for now.'}, {'account_id': 452, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Already approved. Second try. Hope Jenkins is happy with one.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Happy with this overall. I'll defer to Koelker and his wild suggestions on the rest."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

Salvatore,

This looks great to me overall! I really like to approach of making all database accesses within the create_[bulk] API operations use the same session object with subtransactions enabled. 

I've added several in-line comments. One minor issue is that the allow_bulk config value shown in quantum.conf should be True to match the default. Some coordination may also be needed with a patch set I just submitted.

The other issue is whether the approach of passing around the session object should be used more broadly (in all API operations, rather than just in create)? I'd like to take advantage of this in my provider-networks phase 2 patch set, so I can expand on it there. It would be great to get this patch set merged quickly.

-Bob"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Instead of: 

native_bulk = cfg.CONF.DATABASE.native_bulk_support

Why not do something like:

native_bulk = self.plugin.support_native_bulk()

Each plugin would implement support_native_bulk() to return either True or False, depending on whether or not it supports native bulk.

QuantumDbPluginV2.support_native_Bulk() could return True, and plugins that don't want it could override it, or vice versa.

-Bob"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

This looks great! My provider-network WIP patch uses subtransactions similarly, and should also allow enabling native bulk create for linuxbridge. I'm ready to +2 this, except, like Jason, I would prefer to see the plugins' support for native bulk indicated via a plugin function rather than via config."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Derived plugins would be required to opt-in (by implementing support_native_bulk() to return True) if QuantumDbPluginV2.support_native_bulk() returns False. No change to existing plugin code would be required for it to opt-out.

The code that calls support_native_bulk() could make sure the function exists first so plugins not derived from QuantumDbPluginV2 require no change.

I may still be missing your point, and this is not a really critical issue in my opinion, so please use your judgement.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

LGTM. One nit comment'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Fix bulk create operations and make them atomic.

Bug 1024844
Bug 1020639

The API layer is now able to issue bulk create requests to the plugin,
assuming that the plugin supports them. Otherwise, the API layer will
emulate atomic behavior.
This patch also implements OVS plugin support for bulk requests.

Change-Id: I515148d870d0dff8371862fe577c477538364929

commit_message:
Use system CA certificate file

When SSL is being used and the --ca-file option is
not specified use an available system CA file to
verify the server's certificate.

'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:30:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not really comfortable with this. Why can't we do this on the API side? Since that's an information we already have in another form. That seems like polluting the database with something that can be computed on the API side. WDYT Doug?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:30:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm sorry Doug, you're absolutely right. Your patch is good, I though that the first counter returned for 'instance' was an 'absolute' one, whereas it's actually 'cumulative'.

So my remark would be more: why would we keep the 'cumulative' counter, and not replace it by 'absolute'?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:30:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Do you mean the more generic counter that appears first in the list? That's a good question. :-)"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

One of the most common questions for the API will be "how long was an instance running as a certain flavor." In order to answer that, the client needs a way to filter the event data based on the metadata. This is the same problem we discussed a while back in the context of instances changing size in the middle of a billing or polling period.

Collecting a separate meter that includes the instance size lets us use the simple API to calculate duration, min, max, etc. without having to come up with a way to describe the instance metadata through the query API and without requiring that any other database engines support querying into the arbitrary metadata (which is easy to do with MongoDB but more difficult with an RDBMS or other backend).

I considered keeping this changeset outside of the core of ceilometer, but since I think this is going to be the most common way people want to calculate usage, I thought including it made sense. I should split up the notifier handler so that each type of meter can be enabled/disabled separately. Would that make the idea more acceptable?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 16:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Add instance counter based on the instance type

We already count the instance and include the type or
flavor in the metadata. However, one of the most common
billing queries will be "how many instances of type X
are there?" This change adds a new counter for the
instance that includes the flavor name in the counter
name, making it easier to calculate the number of
instances of a given type.

This changeset also breaks up the counters so they
are registered using individual entry points. This
will allow us to enable/disable each one separately
when the collector is deployed.

Finally, this changeset corrects the "type" field for
the "instance" counter to "absolute" instead of
"cumulative".

Change-Id: I08842096209e866e51ef0833ef529315b4f7a938
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

subject: Move results filtering to  db.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-08-06 21:13:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Do we support DBs other than mysql and postgres?  If so, this will break behavior on them.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-08-06 21:47:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Without knowing about the guts of sqlalchemy, it does *seem* like there would be an alternative way of providing this that doesn't end up being implementation specific, which is bad news. As much as I can appreciate the need for an alternative, I don't recall those two being the only supported DB implementations ( though one could probably argue that the db drivers already implicitly force some implementations on us)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-06 21:48:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/6405/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/2235/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/7547/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/3727/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/3757/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/6491/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-06 21:55:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Maybe it's worth splitting it? Exact filter would be just great.

Regex is bound to be more controversial, although backend shouldn't be an issue. Sqlite, mysql, postgres, mssql, informix, oracle and maybe more do support regex in searches, so backends are mostly ok."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-08-06 22:06:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There's not a better way to do it generically w/ sqlalchemy.  I was trying to find a way when I implemented the regex filtering.. and IIRC, what Alex has done here is the only way.  I made the decision to do it client side, so it'd work for all DB choices.  I'd definitely prefer it to be done DB side, though... I don't know if it would be acceptable to state in docs that it only works for postgres and mysql.  If we determine that, this patch will need a modification to skip filtering if engine isn't mysql or postgres."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-08-07 15:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Would making regex filtering a flag be better, maybe we could have a flag for what operation to do? We could also default to doing exact filtering on what would be regex filtering.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-08-07 18:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-08-07 18:28:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Many db backends support MATCH and LIKE operators but they are far from POSIX regex matching. Informix and MSSQL do not seem to have any support for regexes.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-08-07 18:46:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-08-07 18:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Move results filtering to  db.

This patch moves exact filter and regex filter matching on the listing of
instances to the database query. This is important so that we can eventually do
all pagination through the database.

If the db backend does not support regex matching then the SQL 'LIKE' operator
will be used instead.

Change-Id: If9dd644066787f0f3667992f23e5c33b1dc90286

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-05 08:08:53.000000000', 'message': "Use custom encoding for RingData, not pickle.

Serialize RingData in a versioned, custom format which is a combination
of a JSON-encoded header and .tostring() dumps of the
replica2part2dev_id arrays.  This format deserializes hundreds of times
faster than rings serialized with Python 2.7's pickle (a significant
performance regression for ring loading between Python 2.6 and Python
2.7).  Fixes bug 1031954.

swift.common.ring.ring.RingData is now responsible for serialization and
deserialization of its data via a new load() class method and save()
object method.  The new implementation is backward-compatible; if a ring
does not begin with a new-style magic string, it is assumed to be an
old-style pickle-dumped ring and is handled as before.  So new Swift
code can read old rings, but old Swift code will not be able to read
newly-serialized rings. THIS SHOULD BE MENTIONED PROMINENTLY IN THE
RELEASE NOTES.

I didn't want to bite of more than necessary, so I didn't mess with
builder file serialization.

Change-Id: I799b9a4c894d54fb16592443904ac055b2638e2d
"}]
commit_message:
Use custom encoding for RingData, not pickle.

Serialize RingData in a versioned, custom format which is a combination
of a JSON-encoded header and .tostring() dumps of the
replica2part2dev_id arrays.  This format deserializes hundreds of times
faster than rings serialized with Python 2.7's pickle (a significant
performance regression for ring loading between Python 2.6 and Python
2.7).  Fixes bug 1031954.

swift.common.ring.ring.RingData is now responsible for serialization and
deserialization of its data via a new load() class method and save()
object method.  The new implementation is backward-compatible; if a ring
does not begin with a new-style magic string, it is assumed to be an
old-style pickle-dumped ring and is handled as before.  So new Swift
code can read old rings, but old Swift code will not be able to read
newly-serialized rings. THIS SHOULD BE MENTIONED PROMINENTLY IN THE
RELEASE NOTES.

I didn't want to bite of more than necessary, so I didn't mess with
builder file serialization.

Change-Id: I799b9a4c894d54fb16592443904ac055b2638e2d

commit_message:
Make template params resolution standalone

This makes the two functions for resolving template data (Fn::FindInMap,
Ref, etc.) available outside of a Stack object.

Other programs can then import these functions and see how the template
parameters get resolved.

Change-Id: I92de937a3fb25f907404335cb71554036a807c50
Signed-off-by: Tomas Sedovic <tomas@sedovic.cz>

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-31 14:15:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think the right thing to do is to make:

  instance_type_extra_specs_get
  instance_type_extra_specs_update_or_create
  instance_type_extra_specs_delete

take a flavorid rather than instance_type_id

The only place these methods are used is nova-manage and the flavorextraspecs extension. For both of these cases, it makes sense to use flavorid instead of instance_type_id.

You should be able to modify the InstanceTypeExtraSpecs query to join on the flavorid e.g.:

  model_query(ctxt,
              models.InstanceTypeExtraSpecs).\
      join(models.InstanceTypes,
           models.InstanceTypes.id == models.InstanceTypeExtraSpecs.instance_type_id).\
      filter(models.InstanceTypes.flavorid==flavorid)'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-31 14:15:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-07-31 19:47:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Can we add a test case for this please? Ideally, a test would have been written that would have prevented this bug in the first place... :)"}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2012-08-01 09:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Mark, thanks for the kind review and suggestion. I will update the patch set to change the DB API. One thing is, after change the query to use the join() with InstanceType table, I can't update with this query directly, otherwise I will get failure like "Only update via a single table query is currently supported". I will investigate a better method for it.

Jay, thanks for the review. In fact currently there is already test cases for both the DB API and the flavor extra_spec extension API, but the test cases failed to catch this issue. I will consider if I can add a case to cover this issue, although not quite sure yet.'}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2012-08-03 10:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2012-08-03 10:50:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Mark, I changed the query to use subquery instead of join now.


Jay, for the test, I checked current test case. The reason that this issue was not caught by the current test case is because current test case is using a fake DB interface, thus avoid such issue.

Ine method is, instead of using fake db interface, we should have the test cases (under nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/contrib/test_flavors_extra_specs.py) to use real db interface, But I noticed that most of the case under that directory are using  fake db interface, instead of real db interface. 
If it's ok  to change the test case using real data base, I will create another patch for it.

But I don't think we should include that changes in this patch, because that's two different topic. Do you agree?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-03 10:57:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

bug 1031263

The nova database API use instance_type id as parameter to access flavor

Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Flavor extra specs extension use instance_type id

bug 1031263

The nova database API use instance_type id as parameter to access flavor
extra spec. However, the flavor extra_specs API extension use flavor_id as
parameter wrongly.

As the instance_type ID is a purely nova internal ID, the database should
not expose it and instead use flavor_id as the parameter

Change-Id: I5f509cb7c4457d8c399df32f559a874d498be762
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

commit_message:
xenapi: ensure all calls to agent get logged

In some cases, a call to an agent wouldn't get logged since the caller
was expected to log and not all did this. Move this to the callee so
the caller doesn't need to do anything extra.

Change-Id: Ie16a372187c9215028475522eef53bca9a5cf4d8

in the code use "_". Sync up the two.

Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

The current implementation interprets set_default('foo', None) and
set_override('foo', None) as 'clear the existing default or override',
which makes it impossible to override a value with None.

This patch adds support for overriding with a None value by adding
a special internal class. set_override('foo', None) will now override
the existing value with None. This is a slight change to the existing
behavior, so this patch adds two calls for the old functionality of
clearing defaults and overrides. Example syntax for the new calls
are shown below:

conf.clear_default('foo')
conf.clear_override('foo')

The patch also updates the tests to reflect the change in functionality
and adds new tests to verify the new functionality.

Fixes bug 1035478

commit_message:
Allow set_default and set_override to use None

The current implementation interprets set_default('foo', None) and
set_override('foo', None) as 'clear the existing default or override',
which makes it impossible to override a value with None.

This patch adds support for overriding with a None value by adding
a special internal class. set_override('foo', None) will now override
the existing value with None. This is a slight change to the existing
behavior, so this patch adds two calls for the old functionality of
clearing defaults and overrides. Example syntax for the new calls
are shown below:

conf.clear_default('foo')
conf.clear_override('foo')

The patch also updates the tests to reflect the change in functionality
and adds new tests to verify the new functionality.

Fixes bug 1035478

Change-Id: Iee5e20e44da9bef6b86e0483ab0b48b625fe503c

commit_message:
Tilde expansion for --config-file and --config-dir

Fixes bug #1012671

Allow a filename starting with ~ or ~user to be passed for
--config-file or --config-dir.

Change-Id: I67705401ed1c35c0cc2161095e36616552740aba

Putting this changeset in WIP while the commnity finalizes design decisions.
There is still disagremeent on what a public network means so this should not appear as an attempt to force the design in a given way. Please regard it as a "corollary" to the design propoosal at the moment. 

Changes to db model are almost non-existant, apart, of course, for the 'public' attribute. In this example, no operations have been added and all the authentication work is handled through the policy engine. This means that the public network policy is quite configurable, thus allowing different quantum administrators to give different meanings to the term "public".

To test the code as it is, regular Quantum users needs to have the "QuantumUser" role. This can be changed according to your needs by editing policy.json.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

I am not a fan of databases at all :)
Working on the policy engine, in my opinion, gives us a level of flexibility we could not achieve if we 'hardcoded' the logic for this kind of networks in the 'usual' processing layer, by which I mean db_base_plugin.

Also, the kind of 'extended' check we do for public_or_network_owner, would probably required an extra db access anyway. As this kind of information (ownership) does not change over time in the current model, and will probably never change in the future, or change with a very little frequency, I propose to add some form of caching to the policy engine. 

It should not take more than a few lines of code. What do you reckon?"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

Patch Set 1: Work In Progress
Putting this changeset in WIP while the commnity finalizes design decisions. There is still disagremeent on what a public network means so this should not appear as an attempt to force the design in a given way. Please regard it as a "corollary" to the design propoosal at the moment.
Changes to db model are trivial, as we just introduced the 'public' attribute. In this example, no operations have been added and all the authentication work is handled through the policy engine. This means that the public network policy is quite configurable, thus allowing different quantum administrators to give different meanings to the term "public".
To test the code as it is, regular Quantum users needs to have the "QuantumUser" role. This can be changed according to your needs by editing policy.json.

Please do review this patch anyway, as your feedback is extremely appreciated!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> But what is execution? 

We have not yet defined what "execution" means for a Quantum Object. Among the reasons for which it was decided to add a full bitmask of permission there was finding a solution which might be flexible enough to adapt to future changes without the need of changing the API each time.

> How do we limit the owner tenant to write the network? 

Although in theory you can configure access rights as you like, the only ones that work at the moment are 600 (rw- --- ---) and 644 (rw- r-- r--).
As stated earlier, the introduction of this style for defining permission is to be future proof. 

> what is the semantic of writing and execution on network? 

When a user has write access to the network, he/she is allowed to modify network attributes.
Execution semantics are undefined now. The 'x' bits are there anyway and can be leveraged for future use.

> about second group of rwx, what is for? for owner group? Do we have owner group concept? 

The second triad, as stated in comments in the source code, is ignored at the moment. I don't think it will be used for the owner group, because we don't have a group concept in keystone, and also because in linux filesystem that triad is not really for the owner's group, but for the currrent user group. Ideally you would map each triad (owner, group, and world) to different keystone roles.

> If we have, what is the semantic for reading, writing and execution about third group of rwx, what is for? for other tenants? What is the semantic for reading, writing and execution.

The third triad is mapped by default to a QuantumUser role. See policy.json. Users of Quantum can then decide to map world to whatever they like.

The current patch implements the consensus which came out of the Quantum IRC meeting a two weeks ago. Of course, nothing is committed. If other people feel strongly against this permission access mechanism, I will be happy to revert to a flag based solution, although 'public' raised some concerns about the name. My personal idea is that it is not necesary to define all the semantics now, but as long as we have the mechanism in place we can them discuss the semantics in detail at the next summit.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (28 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I kind of had a suspect that the discussion over public networks was far from over.

At this stage I think that for Folsom, reverting to the simple flag is the best option. "Public" has been criticised for its resemblance to the concept of "network with public IPs". Hence, from the various proposal that rained on me a few weeks ago, I would choose "Shared", with a boolean value.
I reckon that we want to avoid enumerated string as much as possible. 
And since at this stage a network is either shared or not, the boolean flag makes sense. 

Please note that we will definitely avoid any backward-incompatible change in Grizzly. So this flag will stay there, even if then we will implement a full ACL solution. This should be easily feasible IMHO.

Coming back to Matt's comments, the choice fell on linux-style permissions because it represents an easy to understand and widespread ACL model. The difference in our case is that the second and third triad would map to some groups that are then specified in policy.json, as there is (and there will not be) any concept of "group" and "world". But I understand we can do much better than that.

One thing I would like to preserve, even if reverting to a single flag, is the extension to the policy engine (that will be adapted for dealing with a single flag rather than a permission bitmask). This is because the rule-based policy engine in openstack common required some kind of hackey tricks for implementing the "read" policy on shared networks (see patchset 1 for details)'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Looks like the root cause of the problem is an unchecked corner case, when authZ is checked for returned objects. Apparently the conversion function is being invoked, but the attributes is set to the unexpected value ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED.

I will look into this because, as GaryK points out, the root cause might be somewhere else, and not necessarily on permissions.

Following, other reviewers comment, it seems sensible to have only a flag and not a full permission mask for Folsom. We will have a session at the summit where we will decide how ACL for Quantum objects should be implemented. I will be more than happy to lead the work.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Work In Progress

I'm working on reviewers comments, and the next patch is going to be fairly different from this one."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (2 inline comments)

Answering Yong's comment (sorry I missed them before pushing patch 11)

1) rule:update_network
Verifies user is authorized to perform the update_network operation
2) rule:update_network:shared
Verifies the user is allowed to use the 'shared' attribute in an update_network operation (implements fine grained control over API operations)
Note: we could (and should) do the same with provider:vlan_id
3) rule:networks:shared:write
Verifies the user is authorized to write on an object he/she does not own. and indeed the corresponding rule is admin_only.

Bottom line: the first two rules match ACLs against operations, the last rule against objects."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

Thanks Salvatore for this patch. Comments have been addressed and core reviewers are satisfied.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: (2 inline comments)

I missed the meeting that settled on this ( I wish I hadn't )

I have some reservations about this implementation, not because of the code itself, but because of the intent. I like that we're trying to encapsulate some better AuthZ like semantics, but I also feel that this doesn't really get us to where we need to be.

It also seems like the roles would map to the groups construct as you see it, so the second triad more cohesively in my mind, but I'll concede that as subjective.

Finally, I think one of the goals we're reaching for in the future is being able to share networks between tenants. Unix-like permissions probably won't give us the flexibility we need. I have hopes that in the not-too-distant future we can design an ACL like system that applies to multiple openstack projects. As such, I see this code going away. 

Beyond any of that, I suspect that we'll have attributes on specific resources that are off-limits to some users and not others, but other attributes that are group/role/tenant modifiable. 

While it's perfectly reasonable to iterate on ideas, this isn't the simplest way to accomplish the goal as we see it now. Seems like the flag would. What do you think?

Also, the execute bit does seem kind of meaningless IMO. In a RESTful API, we're operating on objects, not the underlying constructs. When we say something is writable, we mean the attribute on the network, not data TO the network. I think it ends up coming down to being able to read or set attributes."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Hi,
I am wondering what the quantum cli commands are in order to create, update and query the networks(my own means the tenant_id of the resource is my tenant_id. I can access: my own and other public networks other tenants published.):
1. quantum net-create myname --permissions public|private|666|600|rw-rw-rw-|rw-------
2. quantum net-update myname --permissions public|private|666|600|rw-rw-rw-|rw-------
3. quantum net-list --permissions public to show public networks that I can access
4. quantum net-list --permissions private to show only private ones of my own networks
5. quantum net-list  to show all the networks I can access, according to your impl in this change
We maybe need one more option to show only my own networks:
6. quantum net-list --tenant_id myown_id, which looks strange.
any ideas about above commands?'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 inline comment)

Hi,
about permissions:
r--r--r--, means owner can read, no writing and execution. But what is execution? How do we limit the owner tenant to write the network? what is the semantic of writing and execution on network?
about second group of rwx, what is for? for owner group? Do we have owner group concept? If we have, what is the semantic for reading, writing and execution  
about third group of rwx, what is for? for other tenants? What is the semantic for reading, writing and execution.

In my own opinion, if we cannot define these semantics clearly, we had better resort to just public flag.
Thanks
Yong Sheng Gong"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2012-08-13 12:19:07.000000000', 'message': "Adds the 'public network' concept to Quantum

Implements blueprint quantum-v2-public-networks

This patch allows Quantum to handle public network. It modifies the API adding
a new attribute to the network resource ('public') and enhances the policy
engine in order to handle the behaviour of the service wrt public networks.
Policy.json specify a default behaviour which can be changed by the
administrator, even at runtime.
Tests added to test_db_plugin validate 'obvious' behaviour - such as that only
the ports belonging to a given tenant shoul be returned even when they are
queried on a public network.
Tests added to test_policy instead validate the changes added to the policy
engine.

commit_message:
Adds the 'public network' concept to Quantum

Implements blueprint quantum-v2-public-networks

This patch allows Quantum to handle public networks. It modifies the
API adding a new attribute to the network resource ('shared')
and enhances the policy engine in order to handle the behaviour of
the service wrt shared networks.
Policy.json specifies a default behaviour which can be changed by
the administrator, even at runtime.
Tests added to test_db_plugin validate 'obvious' behaviour - such as
that only the ports belonging to a given tenant should be returned
even when they are queried on a public network.
Tests added to test_policy instead validate the changes added to the
policy engine.

Change-Id: I0087d449a677ed29357cd3cb4d8580bece940fdf

commit_message:
Linux Agent improvements for L3

prereq for bp quantum-l3-fw-nat

- make init_l3 take cidrs, rather than assuming an augmented port object
- make namespace for agent operations optional and allow the namespace
name to be configured.
- allow plug() operation to take an optional bridge parameter indicating
which bridge to plug into
- add namespace support for iptables manager
- make OVS plug() set the IP address, etc. of a device even if it already
exists.

Change-Id: Id4fec9bf7cda30c45b94eccd25e9e54dc5af97b7

Implements part of blueprint disable-server-extensions

Makes sure that auto_disk_config is only accepted in the create
server request if the extension is enabled. Note that the extension
alias is OS-DCF because it also adds output to the server
request.

Change-Id: I59fafe769e1e562e6bf9f6db768acc9b0f8d2b93
'}]
commit_message:
Key auto_disk_config in create server off of ext.

Implements part of blueprint disable-server-extensions

Makes sure that auto_disk_config is only accepted in the create
server request if the extension is enabled. Note that the extension
alias is OS-DCF because it also adds output to the server
request.

Change-Id: I59fafe769e1e562e6bf9f6db768acc9b0f8d2b93

commit_message:
storwize-svc: improved test coverage and fixes.

Added test cases to cover more error paths, now providing 97% test
coverage of the storwize-svc driver. Some tests uncovered bugs in the
driver, which are fixed by this patch. In addition, there are some
fixes to the code included which address comments from the submission
of this driver to nova-volume and sync the two versions.

Change-Id: I7c646885a7f2b1e761725c14940f1d741996beb4

I modified the code according to your comments.

One exception is about logging level. In Horizon, even when api calls raise exceptions almost all api calls does not output log messages. Quantum support is still in the initial stage, so I add log outputs in except statement. Since it seems that LOG.error is too verbose, I use LOG.info() in except statement and LOG.debug() in other places. How do you think?  (If I changed LOG.error(), log messages are output to the console during the test :-( )'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-08-10 00:48:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

Although this seems almost ready, I see two not so minor issues here:

1. The networks are loaded without specifying the tenant_id:

    networks = api.quantum.network_list(request)

This returns all available networks. But when the current tenant is 'Admin', which doesn't have networks, the 'net1' network is shown as a network option in 'Create Instance', thus the 'Create Instance' action fails, because Nova cannot find the network 'net1' for tenant 'Admin' and returns this error:

    The resource could not be found. (HTTP 404) (Request-ID: req-440f8dbc-843d-44b0-b19a-885491f6411c)


2. I'm not sure if this is a problem with quantum, but it's worth mentioning. I'm unable to start quantum in devstack with OpenVSwitch plugin. It gives me some error, but maybe this is a config problem in setup. Using linuxbridge instead works. But then when trying to load the project quotas in the 'Create Instance' form, I get an error for tenant_floating_ip_list which is invoked from tenant_quota_usages, and this is the log:


    [error] ERROR:horizon.exceptions:\x1b[31;1mRecoverable error: The server has either erred or is incapable of performing the requested operation. (HTTP 500) (Request-ID: req-d8e1baa2-4862-4cf7-8182-f5bd8547a6e1)\x1b[0m

I haven't done a code review, but all of the testing I've done has worked, so I agree with Gabriel that it would be smart to merge this large patch and handle the rest as bugs."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-12 15:44:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Hi Tihomir,

Thanks for the testing!  I had typed my comments (but not pushed review) before I saw your note.  

I definitely agree about the list_networks().  We'll also have to figure out how this works with quantum 'shared/public' networks, which are created by the admin but visible to all users.  

In terms of floating IPs, the issue is actually the that quantum v2 API code to handle floating IPs is not merged yet, and thus the nova code to pass those calls to Quantum raises a Not Implemented.  So this is not really an issue with the Horizon code, unless we think Horizon should work around this problema not issue the floating IP request when quantum is in use (however, such a fix would be temporary, as they will soon be supported again)."}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-08-12 16:35:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Hi Tihomir

Thanks for the review. I will continue to work Quantum support to keep it up-to-date.

The first issue you pointed that all networks are listed in instance launch workflow if the tenant is 'admin' is just a bug. In network user panel I use api.quantum.network_list(self.request, tenant_id=tenant_id) to get networks the current tenant owns. I will file a bug about this.

I believe we need some works to support quantum 'shared/public' networks. If the current implementation is used, non-admin users try to update/delete 'shared/public'. This operation is not permitted by quantum and exception will be raised. I will also file this as a bug."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-08-12 20:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Initial support of Quantum V2.

Implementes blueprint quantum-horizon and blueprint readd-quantum-support.
This commit also covers blueprint quantum-workflow-integration.

- Added quantum API layer,
- Added network/subnet/port CRUD operations,
- Added 'Network' user panel,
- Added 'Network' system panel,
- Added 'Networking' tab in instance creation workflow.
- Supported launching an instance with specified network(s)

Change-Id: I7ad608e17cb6fb4f0de02721888e96a68cf926e8

Hi guys,

As I mentioned, the root cause of the jenkins failure wasn't really related to this patch, but it a more general issue related to pulling in Quantum dependencies.  I've tweaked this patch by pulling sg.py into the main nova/network directory (it contains no quantum-specific code anyway) which avoids triggering this issue, and puts us back into the same state that nova is in without this patch.  

I'm going to continue to track this dependency bug as a separate issue, as it is blocking our ability to use jenkins gating for quantum, but we should be able to proceed with this review.  Thanks."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-10 22:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
remove nova code related to Quantum v1 API

bug 1034692

Quantum team is removing all v1 support in Folsom, so this code
will not be used or supported with Quantum Folsom release.

Change-Id: I4c397d5238fcc3a15320e052bdc4735dfec1f176

commit_message:
nova-api-metadata

You can run the nova-api-metadata service instead of running
nova-api if the compute hosts are not API endpoints. This simplifies
configuration.

Change-Id: Ic60ffe53070ab2c7ac2ddd8d30ea50d216fcbe42

[{'created': '2012-08-12 06:24:05.000000000', 'message': 'Update restrictions on allowed v2 image properties

The list of allowed and readonly image attributes has gotten out of
date, so this change updates those lists. This change also adds a
similar check to ensure certain special properties names are reserved as
they would conflict with existing database properties that are either
not presently exposed or exposed under a different name.

Change-Id: I56d6c938dd6a5353e15b3e5ef913fae5b4629d52
'}]
commit_message:
Update restrictions on allowed v2 image properties

The list of allowed and readonly image attributes has gotten out of
date, so this change updates those lists. This change also adds a
similar check to ensure certain special properties names are reserved as
they would conflict with existing database properties that are either
not presently exposed or exposed under a different name.

Change-Id: I56d6c938dd6a5353e15b3e5ef913fae5b4629d52

commit_message:
enable -h | --help after command to show the command usage.

Bug #1023260

we caculate the position of -h|--help and command, if -h|--help
is after command, we replace the command with 'help' command.
Change-Id: Ieb5fc9d37daafd704edb71e35b74dbf83cb69a4c

Please also see https://code.launchpad.net/~soren/nova/eventlet-subprocess/+merge/49698, which indicates we need to use the greenlet version of subprocess."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-12 15:54:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

To elaborate a bit, from looking at logs, the linuxbridge agent clearly is getting an exit_code of 0 when it should be getting 1 when executing commands. This fix sort of addresses one case of this, but isn't a general solution. Changing quantum/agent/linux/utils.py to use:

from eventlet.green import subprocess

seems to resolve the exit code issue in general. The nova version of utils.py has a much more complex implementation of execute(), but it uses evently.green.subprocess and I would think it should work."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-12 15:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This seems to resolve the handling of exit_codes in the linuxbridge agent for me.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-12 15:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Approved

This needs to go in so people can test linuxbridge.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-08-12 15:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-12 15:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-12 15:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

In some cases device check causes an exception

Fixes bug 1035669

Check the stderr in addition to checking the return codes.

Change-Id: I05e469302bc502b540b0c4af5fbd9c712a9bd309

2. I'd like to see the breadcrumb selector for subfolders back. Currently when there are several levels of subfolders, there is no even a notice at what level the user is and no way to navigate back to previous folder.

commit_message:
Add quota commands to change quota of a tenant.

blueprint quantum-api-quotas

quantum quota-show --tenant_id:
if tenant_id is not specified, the server will get tenant_id from context
quantum quota-update --network <num> --port <num>
--subnet <num> --tenant_id <id>:
if tenant_id is not specified, the server will get tenant_id from context
quantum quota-list:
list all tenants' quota values after the updation.
quantum quota-delete --tenant_id <id>:
delete the given tenant's customized quota values.

Change-Id: Ib0efb159bea96837bf4e35eaefa5e172c1c9f34a

commit_message:
Reveal v2 API as v2.0 in versions response

* Report v2.0 API compatibility, not v2
* Allow users to specify '/v2' or '/v2.0' in their request URI

Related to bp api-2

Change-Id: Ia8d41902a2171aad8f06d3ac329a3e3c097cdc90
